articles.title: Turning AI from theory to ROI: The rise of practical enterprise adoption models
articles.description: By turning artificial intelligence from theory into measurable business value, pragmatic enterprise AI adoption focuses on structured, results-driven integration rather than chasing flashy projects. Using a sensible enterprise AI adoption approach converts AI‚Ä¶
articles.author: Brian Njuguna
articles.content: By turning artificial intelligence from theory into measurable business value, pragmatic enterprise AI adoption focuses on structured, results-driven integration rather than chasing flashy projects. ‚Ä¶ [+4333 chars]
articles.full_text: UPDATED 15:22 EDT / OCTOBER 07 2025 by Brian Njuguna By turning artificial intelligence from theory into measurable business value, pragmatic enterprise AI adoption focuses on structured, results-driven integration rather than chasing flashy projects. Using a sensible enterprise AI adoption approach converts AI from buzzword to strategic driver of measurable business outcomes ‚Äî and Cohere Inc. is leading the way. This entails going the extra mile to deliver real return on investment, according to Autumn Moulder (pictured), vice president of engineering at Cohere. Cohere‚Äôs Autumn Moulder talks about enterprise AI adoption. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve really evolved and said, ‚ÄòWhat does an enterprise need to adopt this fundamentally transformational technology?‚Äô‚Äù Moulder asked. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve evolved from, we build the foundation model to let‚Äôs bring in some applications, the North products that we‚Äôve recently developed, to make it easier to adopt AI within the enterprise, to partnering with these companies to say, ‚ÄòHey, we can help you build a custom model. We can help you build a custom agent.‚Äô‚Äù Moulder spoke with theCUBE‚Äôs John Furrier at theCUBE + NYSE Wired: AI Factories ‚Äì Data Centers of the Future event, during an exclusive broadcast on theCUBE, SiliconANGLE Media‚Äôs livestreaming studio. They discussed the critical role of pragmatic enterprise AI adoption, noting innovations developed by Cohere. Partnerships are key to enterprise AI adoption. Scaling AI isn‚Äôt just about software ‚Äî it requires aligning technology, talent, data, processes and strategy. With deep expertise in machine learning, NLP, data engineering and AI governance, Cohere is already leading the way, according to Moulder. ‚ÄúWe very much have focused on that enterprise segment,‚Äù she explained. ‚ÄúWe see this as a place where we can drive a lot of value and really help people navigate this transition. There‚Äôs a recent MIT study that came out about how enterprise partnerships, where you partner with an external entity versus rolling it yourself, [has] like twice the success rate when you‚Äôre looking to adopt AI. We‚Äôve really taken that to heart coming from our foundations of building models.‚Äù Pragmatic enterprise AI adoption goes beyond installing software ‚Äî it demands the right blend of capabilities to tackle real business challenges. Large language models offer adaptability and conversational intelligence, while specialized models deliver precision and domain expertise. Together, they enable versatile, operationally effective AI solutions ‚Äî something Cohere is uniquely positioned to deliver, Moulder pointed out. ‚ÄúWe focus very much on efficiency, which ties it to this idea of large language models, small language models, what‚Äôs the right size model and making sure that we can deliver the point solution whether it‚Äôs a small language model for a highly efficient work flow,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe bring both of those to the table. We see this as an efficiency story and we also see it as a privacy story making sure you can hit both of those pieces.‚Äù Here‚Äôs the complete video interview, part of SiliconANGLE‚Äôs and theCUBE‚Äôs coverage of theCUBE + NYSE Wired: AI Factories ‚Äì Data Centers of the Future event: Support our mission to keep content open and free by engaging with theCUBE community. Join theCUBE‚Äôs Alumni Trust Network, where technology leaders connect, share intelligence and create opportunities. Founded by tech visionaries John Furrier and Dave Vellante, SiliconANGLE Media has built a dynamic ecosystem of industry-leading digital media brands that reach 15+ million elite tech professionals. Our new proprietary theCUBE AI Video Cloud is breaking ground in audience interaction, leveraging theCUBEai.com neural network to help technology companies make data-driven decisions and stay at the forefront of industry conversations. The company's VP of Engineering, Autumn Moulder, emphasizes partnerships and efficiency, noting that external collaborations show double the success rate compared to in-house AI implementations.

articles.title: Jonah Hill Shows Major Weight Loss Transformation on Set of New Movie
articles.description: Jonah Hill is committing to his next movie role in a major way. The Wolf of Wall Street star looked unrecognizable in an eccentric costume highlighting his significant weight loss as he stepped...
articles.content: Lizzo simply wanted to feel better from head to toe.  Once I started working out for mental health, to have balanced mental health or endorphins, so that I don't look at myself in the mirror and feel‚Ä¶ [+896 chars]
articles.full_text: Jonah Hill is committing to his next movie role in a major way. The Wolf of Wall Street star looked unrecognizable in an eccentric costume highlighting his significant weight loss as he stepped out on set of his new comedy Cut Off in Los Angeles Oct. 6. While exiting his trailer, Jonah, 41, donned a skin-tight leopard print turtleneck, blue jeans with black fringe and tan boots. He completed the quirky ensemble by sporting shaggy blonde hair and a pair of cat-eye glasses. The film, which costars Kristen Wiig, follows two siblings whose wealthy parents cut them off financially, according to The Hollywood Reporter. And Jonah is doing more than just take on a major role in front of the camera, he‚Äôs also directing and producing the project from a script he cowrote, with a theatrical release set for July 2026. It‚Äôs not the first time Jonah has transformed his body for a role, either. He previously spoke about gaining weight for the crime comedy War Dogs, later calling one of his celebrity pals for tips on how to tone up after filming. ‚ÄúI called Channing Tatum and said, ‚ÄòHey, if I eat less and go to a trainer, will I get in good shape?‚Äô‚Äù he said during an appearance on The Tonight Show in 2016. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs like, ‚ÄòYeah, you dumb motherf--ker, of course you will. It‚Äôs the simplest thing in the entire world.‚Äô‚Äù But the Oscar nominee has also been candid about struggling with his appearance. In 2021, he penned an open letter detailing his struggles with his weight after photos of him shirtless at the beach were published online. ‚ÄúI don't think I ever took my shirt off in a pool until I was in my mid 30s even in front of family and friends,‚Äù he wrote in a post on his Instagram page, which he deleted in August 2022. ‚ÄúProbably would have happened sooner if my childhood insecurities weren't exacerbated by years of public mockery about my body by press and interviewers.‚Äù But as Jonah went on to note, his self-worth had come a long way since then. ‚ÄúThe idea that the media tries to play me by stalking me while surfing and printing photos like this and it can't phase me anymore is dope,‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúI'm 37 and finally love and accept myself.‚Äù Keep reading to see more stars who have undergone major weight loss transformations‚Ä¶ Trevor Larcom The Fresh Off the Boat alum used to weigh 300 pounds and lost 130, showcasing his journey on TikTok. Tammy Slaton Tammy Slaton may be a star of TLC‚Äôs 1,000-Lb. Sisters, but she didn‚Äôt want to be beholden to that title forever. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm down 500 pounds now, around 500,‚Äù the 38-year-old said in a confessional on an April 2025 episode of her show. ‚ÄúWhen I was at my heaviest, I was 700-plus pounds. Right now, I‚Äôm weighing in at 238.‚Äù She underwent bariatric surgery in 2022, a choice her physician has praised as the right one for her. ‚ÄúTammy has consistently demonstrated her dedication to making sustainable lifestyle changes to maximize the benefits of her surgery,‚Äù Dr. Eric Smith told People in October 2024. ‚ÄúI've emphasized the importance of making small, daily adjustments to ensure not only her continued progress but also her long-term success. She's truly committed to her health journey.‚Äù Jelly Roll It seems as if every time Jelly Roll hits a red carpet, he‚Äôs down a sizable slice of weight. ‚ÄúI started at 540 pounds and I was 357 pounds this morning,‚Äù the singer born Jason DeFord told Pat McAfee in April 2025 during the ESPN host's Big Night Aht live show. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna lose another 100 pounds and go skydiving with my wife in Sweden, baby!" The 6-foot-1 artist admittedly needed to overhaul his relationship with food to get where he wanted to go. "I've always said that I believe obesity is directly connected to mental health," he explained on an October 2024 episode of On Purpose With Jay Shetty. "I know how easy it is for people to go, 'Just quit eatin' so much, just work out, it's so easy!' I wish I looked at food that way.‚Äù Weight was still ‚Äúthe mountain‚Äù in front of him, Jelly Roll noted, but his lifestyle changes were working. "I'm learning, I'm being very diligent with it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI'm taking it serious, I'm drinking a bunch of water, I'm cold plunging, I'm eating right, I'm doing good." Al Roker Al Roker wasn‚Äôt kidding around with the title of his cookbook Recipes to Live By. Because having lost a hard-fought 100 pounds, the longtime TODAY weatherman literally walks the walk (aiming for at least 10,000 steps a day), watching what he eats and fitting in some sort of exercise on a daily basis. ‚ÄúMy mantra is ‚Äòsomething is better than nothing,‚Äô‚Äù he told People in a June 2025 interview. ‚ÄúMaybe you‚Äôll be running marathons or entering weight-lifting contests, but I think most people just want a level of fitness that improves their quality of life.‚Äù Roker underwent gastric bypass surgery in 2002 to get his fitness journey underway, but, he acknowledged, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no magic bullet.‚Äù Surgery is ‚Äúnot the end,‚Äù he advised. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre still going to have to put in the work.‚Äù Jason Kelce While previously known fo
articles.rewritten_text: Actor Jonah Hill unveiled a dramatic weight loss transformation while filming his new comedy "Cut Off" in Los Angeles. Sporting a leopard-print turtleneck and blonde hair, the unrecognizable star is not only acting but also directing and producing the film, which follows siblings cut off from family wealth.

articles.title: Mixed opening day for Rob Dickson and Se√°n Waddilove at 49er World Championships
articles.description: Dublin pair win opener before setbacks in second and third races
articles.author: David Branigan
articles.content: In a reprise of their Olympic debut at Tokyo 2020, Irelands Rob Dickson and Se√°n Waddilove stole a solid race win to open their World Championship series in Sardinia on Tuesday.  The Howth and Skerri‚Ä¶ [+1876 chars]
articles.full_text: In a reprise of their Olympic debut at Tokyo 2020, Ireland‚Äôs Rob Dickson and Se√°n Waddilove stole a solid race win to open their World Championship series in Sardinia on Tuesday. The Howth and Skerries pairing opted to duck behind the main line of boats starting the race after spotting a gap between the fleet and the committee boat. Hitting the line exactly on the signal and already at speed, the IRL99 crew ‚Äúport-tacked‚Äù away from the others in clear air as they headed for mark one with a clear lead. With the advantage of open water ahead, they extended their position over the two laps of the course and scored a memorable first place. However, that victory will be sorely needed as motivation over the coming five day. In the following two races, as the breeze first freshened and then started to fade, spotting the wind shifts against the intensity of the setting sun became challenging. Two deep results of 25th and 20th followed, leaving them with an uphill climb from which they will have to recover over the coming days. The worst race discard will likely see them drop the 25th-place finish, but this year‚Äôs event is trialling a new Olympic medal race format. As usual, the top third of the fleet will initially aim to qualify for the gold fleet. From there, the final race of the gold series will be umpired, meaning no rules protests will be held ashore afterwards which would delay results. The top four boats remaining after that race then qualify for the medal race final. In a major departure from standard competitions until now, the boat that wins the medal race is guaranteed gold. The previous first and second-placed boats would still be guaranteed a medal but would need the final win for the gold. The new format is a trial before a decision is taken by World Sailing on the matter at its annual congress, which will be held in D√∫n Laoghaire early next month. The proposed changes seek to satisfy the International Olympic Committee that the sport can deliver an exciting climax to competitions to address falling television audience numbers.
articles.rewritten_text: Irish sailors Rob Dickson and Se√°n Waddilove secured a dramatic race win at the 49er World Championships in Sardinia, using clever positioning to gain an early lead. However, they struggled in subsequent races, finishing 25th and 20th, complicating their path forward in the five-day competition.

articles.title: Call in Washington: 'Until every hostage is released from Hamas's tunnels'
articles.description: Nearly the entire Cabinet join captivity survivors, 10.7 survivors, and family of the victims and hostages for ceremony marking the 2nd anniversary of the October 7 massacre in Washington DC.
articles.author: Israel National News
articles.content: As negotiations progress and the world marks two years since October 7th, survivors of captivity and family members of hostages gathered in Washington, D.C. to commemorate the anniversary of the mass‚Ä¶ [+3462 chars]
articles.full_text: As negotiations progress and the world marks two years since October 7th, survivors of captivity and family members of hostages gathered in Washington, D.C. to commemorate the anniversary of the massacre today (Tuesday). The events included a cabinet meeting with sixteen cabinet members and senior White House officials, followed by a VIP vigil attended by dignitaries from the White House, ambassadors, and faith leaders, honoring the victims and hostages of October 7th. Secretary of State Marco Rubio stated: ‚ÄúYou have all inspired us. President Trump is committed to putting this tragedy to an end. Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner will head to the region shortly to help bring this matter to a close. I am confident and hopeful that the next time we gather here, it will be to remember that tragic day ‚Äî with all 48 hostages home.‚Äù Secretary of Commerce Howard Lutnick stated: ‚ÄúAlmost all Cabinet members gathered here today to support the urgent call of President Trump, survivors and hostages‚Äô families to release all the hostages now. We are in critical days and we trust Ambassador Wittkoff and the team in Egypt to finalize this agreement for a better future in the Middle East.‚Äù Captivity survivor Noa Argamani said: ‚ÄúI am especially grateful to President Trump for his support and commitment to the hostage deal since the day he was elected. I miss Avinatan more with every passing day. I hold onto hope, every single day, that this nightmare will end soon, and we‚Äôll finally get to live the life we‚Äôve dreamed of.‚Äù Captivity survivor Doron Steinbrecher said: ‚ÄúWhen the first deal collapsed, I was told I was going home. I believed it. For a moment, I felt hope. But then the sounds of war returned, and I knew it was over. The despair was crushing. After 471 days, I walked out of Gaza. But even now, I cannot truly move on. For us, there is no ‚Äòafter.‚Äô The trauma follows you. It lives in your body. And as long as others remain in Gaza, a part of me remains there too. I cannot fully begin to heal while they are still suffering.‚Äù Arbel Yehoud, captivity survivor and partner of Ariel Cunio, stated: ‚ÄúI will forever be grateful to President Trump for saving my life and getting me home to my family, to my loved ones. Only because of your courage and determination, Mr. President, I stand here today. And I dare to ask, please, bring back my Ariel, his brother David, and all the remaining hostages. They must come home. Now.‚Äù Lishay Miran-Lavi, survivor of the 10.7 attack and wife of Omri Miran, said: ‚ÄúI came because it‚Äôs not over until it‚Äôs over - until every one of them is released from Hamas‚Äôs tunnels. Until Omri and the 47 others are home. This deal ensures that every hostage will be released within the first 72 hours. Israel has already agreed. Hamas claims it has too. Now it is time to act. No more politics. No more excuses. No more delays.‚Äù Captivity survivor Keith Siegel said: ‚ÄúOn October 7th, 251 innocent people were kidnapped to Gaza. 42 were killed and murdered in captivity. In the past 2 years, through diplomacy and negotiations, 140 hostages have been brought back. I am here, standing in front of you today as a result of a life saving agreement. That agreement was secured through leaders who made it a priority.‚Äù Liran Berman, brother of Gali and Ziv Berman, said: ‚ÄúPresident Trump, please, don‚Äôt stop now. You‚Äôve brought us this far. Finish what you started, what we know and trust you can. Bring my brothers home. Bring all of the hostages home. Let this be the moment the world finally acts with courage and compassion. For those still alive who are waiting to be freed, and for those who must be given the dignity of a proper burial.‚Äù
articles.rewritten_text: Survivors of Hamas captivity and families of remaining hostages gathered in Washington D.C. to mark two years since October 7th. During meetings with cabinet members and White House officials, they urged continued efforts to secure the release of 48 hostages still held in Gaza's tunnels.

articles.title: The Disney Advantage: How Women Leaders Are Transforming Women‚Äôs Sport Visibility And Growth
articles.description: Through Disney and ESPN's strategic, long-term investment and representative leadership approach, championed by women executives, they have driven unprecedented growth in women's sports viewership and coverage.
articles.author: Lindsey Darvin, Contributor,   Lindsey Darvin, Contributor  https://www.forbes.com/sites/lindseyedarvin/
articles.content: LAS VEGAS, NEVADA - SEPTEMBER 30: ESPN reporter Holly Rowe interviews Chelsea Gray #12, A'ja Wilson #22, Jackie Young #0, Aaliyah Nye #13 and Dana Evans #11 of the Las Vegas Aces after the team's 107‚Ä¶ [+17163 chars]
articles.full_text: ByLindsey Darvin, Contributor. Disney and ESPN's strategic, long-term investment and representative leadership, championed by women executives, have driven unprecedented growth in women's sports. Record WNBA viewership and significant advertising revenue demonstrate this isn't a fleeting trend but a powerful movement. Their approach, treating women's sports as a core business, proves representative leadership yields strong cultural and financial results. The numbers tell a story that Rita Ferro, President of Global Advertising at Disney, has been building toward for years. The 2024 WNBA season delivered ESPN‚Äôs second most-watched coverage ever, up 170 percent year-over-year, with 54 million unique viewers and 22 games seeing over one million viewers tune in. The 2025 WNBA regular season built on this viewership success as ESPN networks recorded their most watched WNBA regular season, and a 6 percent increase from 2024 viewership numbers. The 2025 regular season games averaged 1.3 million viewers, including ESPN‚Äôs most-watched WNBA game on record when 2.7 million viewers tuned in on May 17 to watch the Chicago Sky at Indiana Fever on ABC. For Ferro and her ESPN executive counterparts, this growth was inevitable, not some huge payout from a risky bet. "Women‚Äôs sports are one of the fastest-growing opportunities in all of sports, full stop," Ferro said. "The trajectory is undeniable. We‚Äôre already seeing breakthrough moments with record ratings, sold-out arenas, and cultural relevance that rivals any other property.‚Äù Importantly, it‚Äôs becoming clear that this trajectory of women‚Äôs sport growth didn‚Äôt happen by accident. Instead, it‚Äôs the product of strategic decisions made by women leaders at both Disney and ESPN who saw opportunity when others saw uncertainty. These women leaders have been building up business cases for women‚Äôs sport while others continued to consider the industry to be a charity case. As noted by Ferro, ‚Äú‚Ä¶diversity of thought leads to better outcomes. The more perspectives you have at the table, the stronger the decisions. And for me personally, as a working mom, I feel a responsibility to set an example, not just for my daughter, but for all young women watching what‚Äôs possible.‚Äù These sentiments became even more apparent across my recent conversations with four key Disney and ESPN executives. In addition to Rita Ferro, three ESPN executives (Roz Durant with it the Executive Vice President, Programming & Acquisitions, Tina Thornton, who is the Executive Vice President, Creative Studio and Marketing, and Chara-Lynn Aguiar, who is the Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer), shared similar sentiments that intentional and representative leadership has been able to create what Durant described as unstoppable momentum, "the sky is the limit and women's sports are on a rocket ship!" These women leaders noted that ESPN has played a key role in the women‚Äôs sports boom through decades of strategic investment, innovative partnerships, and what Ferro described as ‚Äúconviction plus proof,‚Äù further noting that, ‚ÄúESPN was one of the first to invest heavily in women‚Äôs sports, giving it prime exposure and treating it with the same seriousness as men‚Äôs sports.‚Äù This leadership approach provides an important blueprint for other organizations, as both Disney and ESPN are showing that representative leadership drives both cultural change and business results, even within an industry that has historically been dominated by men and men's sports. As Ferro put it, ‚Äúrepresentation matters. If you can see it, you can be it. Visibility of women leaders both inspires the next generation and normalizes women in positions of influence. That‚Äôs one of the reasons ESPN has doubled down on women‚Äôs sports, because visibility creates momentum.‚Äù And this representative leadership approach has led to one of the best sport investments to date. While other media competitors are playing catchup in trying to cash in on the momentum across women‚Äôs sports, the women leaders I spoke with at both Disney and ESPN each made sure to explain that they have been here all along. "Women‚Äôs Sports is part of ESPN‚Äôs DNA," said Tina Thornton, who has been with the company for more than 30 years. "ESPN isn‚Äôt new to Women‚Äôs Sports. We‚Äôve been a partner of the NCAA Women‚Äôs Tournament since 1996." Chara-Lynn Aguiar reinforced these points from Thornton, sharing that "this is not a new strategy for us, we have been investing in the space for many years and we have credibility." She noted that "male and female executives alike all champion women's sports" and points to recent examples including the "WNBA, NCAA, NWSL, WLL, as well as our programming team optimizing our schedule." The difference in how ESPN has worked with women‚Äôs sports over the decades, especially once compared with the later-arriving competitors, have been the efforts to treat women's sports as more of a core business strategy rather than experimental or charity programming.
articles.rewritten_text: Disney and ESPN's women executives are driving unprecedented growth in women's sports viewership. The 2024 WNBA season saw a 170 percent increase in ESPN coverage, with 54 million unique viewers. Leaders like Rita Ferro credit diverse leadership for this success, treating women's sports as core business.

articles.content: EXCLUSIVE: Sam Jaeger (The Handmaid‚Äôs Tale, The Devil in Ohio) has joined the recurring cast of Apple TV+‚Äòs Bad Monkey, sources tell Deadline. The series hails from executive producer Bill Lawrence a‚Ä¶ [+1691 chars]
articles.full_text: EXCLUSIVE: Sam Jaeger (The Handmaid‚Äôs Tale, The Devil in Ohio) has joined the recurring cast of Apple TV+‚Äòs Bad Monkey, sources tell Deadline. The series hails from executive producer Bill Lawrence and is led by Vince Vaughn, who also exec produces. Based on Carl Hiaasen‚Äôs New York Times bestselling novel of the same name, Season 1 of Bad Monkey follows Andrew Yancy (Vaughn), who has been bounced from the Miami Police Department and is now a health inspector in the Keys. But after stumbling upon a case that begins with a human arm fished up by tourists, he realizes that if he can prove murder, he‚Äôll be back in. He just needs to get past a trove of Floridian oddballs and one bad monkey. Related Stories Casting 'Presumed Innocent': Fiona Shaw Joins Season 2 Of Apple TV+ Legal Drama News 'The Morning Show' Star Karen Pittman Talks Mia's "Painful Realization" That The Status Quo Remains Intact At UBN After A Crushing Blow In Episode 403 Season 2 will be based on a new original story. In addition to Vaughn, Ortiz will reprise his Season 1 role of Rogelio, a police detective and Yancy‚Äôs best friend, as a series regular. Previously announced lead cast also includes John Malkovich as Spencer, the head of a major South Florida criminal organization, as well as Yvonne Strahovski, Jaeger‚Äôs former co-star on the Hulu hit series The Handmaid‚Äôs Tale. Watch on Deadline In addition to The Handmaid‚Äôs Tale, Jaeger also recently starred opposite Emily Deschanel in Netflix‚Äôs limited series The Devil in Ohio. He is well known for his role as Joel Graham in the NBC series Parenthood. He also played lead roles in the NBC series Law & Order True Crime: The Menendez Brothers, the ABC miniseries When We Rise, Tell Me a Story for CBS All-Access, Marc Cherry‚Äôs Why Women Kill, and Ryan Murphy/Brad Falchuk‚Äôs The Politician opposite Gwyneth Paltrow. His film credits include Blumhouse‚Äôs The Wolf Man, Steven Soderbergh‚Äôs Traffic, Clint Eastwood‚Äôs American Sniper, Paul Thomas Anderson‚Äôs Inherent Vice, and opposite Jessica Chastain and Andrew Garfield in The Eyes of Tammy Faye. He is repped by Greene Talent, Entertainment 360 and attorney John Meigs. Get our Breaking News Alerts and Keep your inbox happy. Comments On Deadline Hollywood are monitored. So don't go off topic, don't impersonate anyone, and don't get your facts wrong. Comment Name Email Website Œî

articles.title: Gordon Ramsay‚Äôs ‚ÄòKnife Edge‚Äô on Apple TV+ spotlights culinary world‚Äôs chase for Michelin glory
articles.description: Apple TV+'s new documentary series ‚ÄúKnife Edge: Chasing Michelin Stars,‚Äù executive produced by Gordon Ramsay and Studio Ramsay Global‚Ä¶ The post Gordon Ramsay‚Äôs ‚ÄòKnife Edge‚Äô on Apple TV+ spotlights culinary world‚Äôs chase for Michelin glory appeared first on Ma‚Ä¶
articles.author: MacDailyNews
articles.content: Knife Edge: Chasing Michelin Stars premieres Friday, October 10th, on Apple TV+.  Apple TV+‚Äôs new documentary series Knife Edge: Chasing Michelin Stars, executive produced by Gordon Ramsay and Studio‚Ä¶ [+2526 chars]
articles.full_text: Apple TV+‚Äôs new documentary series ‚ÄúKnife Edge: Chasing Michelin Stars,‚Äù executive produced by Gordon Ramsay and Studio Ramsay Global, premieres globally on Friday, October 10th. The eight-part series, hosted by Jesse Burgess, food expert and co-founder of the global food and travel platform Topjaw, takes viewers inside the emotionally charged, high-stakes world of fine dining ‚Äî capturing the pressure and ambition that define the road to Michelin recognition. Marie-louise Gumuchian for Reuters: ‚Äé ‚Äú(It) is a sort of a real reflection on what goes on in these businesses: what‚Äôs at stake, what kind of jeopardy is up for grabs and then the emotions,‚Äù Ramsay told Reuters. ‚ÄúThis is (an)‚Ä¶unscripted, real version of life in the culinary world and the extent you go to for the badge of honour ‚Ä¶ Actors want Oscars, football players want F.A. Cup winners‚Äô medals, chefs want Michelin stars.‚Äù Episodes show host Jesse Burgess meeting chefs as they compose menus, primp up dishes and seek to impress that lone diner who may be a secret Michelin inspector. There is also input from the anonymous Michelin inspectors, voiced by actors. ‚ÄúWe ask them questions and they answer. In reality, it was all ‚Ä¶ very secretive so that none of the producers or nobody actually saw the real-life inspectors,‚Äù Burgess said. ‚ÄúThey just judge the food on the plate.‚Äù Ramsay received his first Michelin star when he was head chef at London restaurant Aubergine. His own Restaurant Gordon Ramsay has held three stars since 2001‚Ä¶ Asked if he still gets nervous when Michelin issues new editions of the guide, Ramsay said: ‚ÄúI do get nervous ‚Ä¶ no one likes losing ‚Ä¶ (going) down to even two stars is unique, but ‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs major headlines if you do. I‚Äôm often asked, ‚ÄòWhat would you do if you did lose a star?‚Äô Then, I‚Äôd fight and win it back.‚Äù ‚Äé MacDailyNews Note: Apple TV+ is available on the Apple TV app in over 100 countries and regions, on over 1 billion screens, including iPhone, iPad, Apple TV, Apple Vision Pro, Mac, popular smart TVs from Samsung, LG, Sony, VIZIO, TCL and others, Roku and Amazon Fire TV devices, Chromecast with Google TV, PlayStation and Xbox gaming consoles, and at tv.apple.com, for $9.99 per month with a seven-day free trial for new subscribers. articles.full_text: The competition is getting even more fierce! "Dancing With the Stars" is expected to air its fourth episode of Season 34 tonight. Last episode, Robert Irwin, gave fans a show when he ripped his shirt off mid-performance during TikTok Night of the program. The stunt, along with his superior skills on the dance floor, earned him a score of 22/30, breaking his weeks-long tie with ‚ÄúThe Secret Lives of Mormon Wives‚Äù star Whitney Leavitt for the top position. Leavitt, on the other hand, received one of the best scores of the night once again when she danced alongside her partner, Mark Ballas, on the show. She and Olympic gold medalist Jordan Chiles received the top score of 24/30. Sadly, one contestant went home in a shocking elimination. Scroll below to see who got the axe and how you can watch tonight's episode of "Dancing With the Stars." Yes, ‚ÄúDancing with the Stars‚Äù will air its fourth episode for Season 34 tonight on Oct. 7. The competition series airs live on ABC and Disney+ at 8 p.m. ET/PT and 7 p.m. CT. Episodes will be available to stream the next day on ABC.com and Hulu. The theme for the Oct. 7 episode of ‚ÄúDancing with the Stars‚Äù is Disney. See the list of songs here. Last week, Fifth Harmony singer Lauren Jauregui got eliminated from the competition. She performed a cha cha to her hit single ‚ÄúWork From Home‚Äù while three of her Fifth Harmony bandmates ‚Äî Normani, Ally Brooke, and Dinah Jane ‚Äî watched in the audience. Camila Cabello, who left the group in 2016, was not in attendance. She and comedian Andy Richter received the lowest score of a night, which was an 18/30, and ultimately, Jauregui went home. When asked how she felt about being eliminated, the singer said, ‚ÄúPissed." Joyann Jeffrey is a trending news reporter based in New York City

articles.title: Busy Philipps Shares the Workout Behind Her 'Sexy Mom Era'
articles.description: Busy Philipps thinks we could all stand to be a little more honest in our workout classes. Admittedly, it doesn't take a ton of convincing to get Philipps to share her unfiltered thoughts - but in agreeing to wear a hot mic during a Zumba class, she might've ‚Ä¶
articles.author: Chandler Plante
articles.content: Busy Philipps thinks we could all stand to be a little more honest in our workout classes. Admittedly, it doesn't take a ton of convincing to get Philipps to share her unfiltered thoughts but in agre‚Ä¶ [+2755 chars]
articles.full_text: Busy Philipps thinks we could all stand to be a little more honest in our workout classes. Admittedly, it doesn't take a ton of convincing to get Philipps to share her unfiltered thoughts ‚Äî but in agreeing to wear a hot mic during a Zumba class, she might've unlocked some of her most candid takes yet. "My hips have not seen this much action in a while," she says mid-class in a video shared on Oct. 6. "I look like I'm in a high school theater production." This venture into unfamiliar terrain is just one of the ways Philipps is stepping into her "sexy mom era" ‚Äî a phase of life all about feeling confident and exploring what brings you joy. Although she's previously experienced symptoms of star student syndrome ‚Äî trying to be the best in class or working to impress the fitness instructor ‚Äî these days, she works out with herself in mind. "The more empowered you are in yourself and what's true to you, the sexier it is to other people," she says. "That's the thing that people respond to with me. They respond to the fact that I'm a little bit DGAF." "Are people going to judge me? What if I need more water than some? What if I pee?" Unfamiliar workout classes can definitely be intimidating, but as long as she's being honest, this is some of the most fun Philipps has had in a fitness setting. "I have been looking for a new cardio workout that I don't hate," she tells Popsugar. "I think it's a very relatable experience, right? You're trying a new thing for the first time, you're going by yourself, you're like, 'Oh God, am I wearing the right stuff? Are people going to judge me? What if I need more water than some? What if I pee?'" That said, the fitness world and "sexy mom era" can be difficult to embrace, especially when you're faced with the pressure to make it all look picture-perfect. Philipps's advice? "You have to let go of other people's expectations and feeling beholden to other people's ideas of what you should be doing," she says. "Get in touch with what you want to do." She's doing her part by going on trips, re-uniting with old friends, and yes, trying new workouts that feel fun, not frustrating. Amid busy schedules and relentless feedback from the world around us, Philipps knows it can be hard to get grounded . . . but it's worth doing anyway. "It's really important for us, all of us, to get out of our heads and into our bodies, especially women," she says. "If you can take an hour every day or three times a week to just reconnect with your body, that is gonna pull you into your sexy mom era, for sure." Chandler Plante (she/her) is a social producer and staff writer for the Health & Fitness team at Popsugar. She has over five years of industry experience, previously working as an editorial assistant for People magazine, a social media manager for Millie magazine, and a contributor for Bustle Digital Group. She has a degree in magazine journalism from Syracuse University and is based in Los Angeles.
articles.rewritten_text: Actress Busy Philipps embraces her "sexy mom era" through candid Zumba workouts, wearing a hot mic to share unfiltered thoughts during class. She encourages women to focus on personal enjoyment rather than others' expectations, emphasizing body connection through fun fitness activities several times weekly.

articles.title: Texas Ends ABA‚Äôs Accreditation Monopoly in the Lone Star State
articles.description: In the little over 100 years since its founding, the American Bar Association has transformed from an organization designed to promote best practices in the... Read More The post Texas Ends ABA‚Äôs Accreditation Monopoly in the Lone Star State appeared first on‚Ä¶
articles.author: Zack Smith
articles.content: In the little over 100 years since its founding, the American Bar Association has transformed from an organization designed to promote best practices in the legal profession to one promoting partisan‚Ä¶ [+3324 chars]
articles.full_text: David Buono/Icon Sportswire via Getty Images In the little over 100 years since its founding, the American Bar Association has transformed from an organization designed to promote best practices in the legal profession to one promoting partisan political positions that are immoral, illegal, and unethical. But despite its woke commitments, the ABA has remained the nation‚Äôs only nationally recognized law school accreditor. On top of that, many states specifically require that those who sit for their state‚Äôs bar exam must first have graduated from an ABA-accredited law school. The ABA long ago ceased to promote best practices for legal education‚Äîleading my colleague at The Heritage Foundation and me to call for federal and state actions to end the ABA‚Äôs accreditation monopoly. In April, President Donald Trump issued an executive order explicitly criticizing the ABA‚Äôs accrediting arm for its problematic DEI practices and ordering the Department of Education to ‚Äúhold accountable [consistent with applicable law], including through denial, monitoring, suspension, or termination of accreditation recognition, accreditors who fail to meet the applicable recognition criteria or otherwise violate Federal law.‚Äù Trump clarified that accreditors violate federal law by ‚Äúrequiring institutions seeking accreditation to engage in unlawful discrimination in accreditation-related activity under the guise of ‚Äòdiversity, equity, and inclusion‚Äô initiatives.‚Äù That‚Äôs after U.S. Attorney General Pam Bondi had already notified the ABA it was likely breaking the law by pushing its DEI policies. Last week, Texas became the first state to adopt our main state-level recommendation, with its supreme court eliminating the requirement that an individual has to have graduated from an ABA-accredited law school to sit for the bar in that state. ‚ÄúThe Court is of the tentative opinion that the ABA should no longer have the final say on whether a law school‚Äôs graduates are eligible to sit for the Texas bar exam and become licensed to practice law in Texas,‚Äù the Texas Supreme Court wrote. Now, it falls to the Texas Supreme Court itself to decide whether a law school qualifies as an ‚Äúapproved law school‚Äù eligible to have its graduates sit for, and become members of, the Texas bar. The change won‚Äôt take effect until early in 2026‚Äîafter a period for public comment‚Äîbut this is undoubtedly a step in the right direction. Texas isn‚Äôt the only state considering such changes. Florida‚Äôs Supreme Court is considering a similar step, and other states will likely follow suit‚Äîas they should. After all, the ABA tried to bully George Mason University‚Äôs law school into discriminating against students based on race‚Äîeven going so far as to threaten the school‚Äôs accreditation unless it applied different admissions standards based on race. The ABA has pushed policies that likely violate the First Amendment by restricting what attorneys can‚Äîand cannot‚Äîsay. And it even‚Äîabsurdly‚Äîclaimed the Equal Rights Amendment had become the 28th Amendment to the United States Constitution. That position proved so radical, legally untenable, and dangerous that even President Joe Biden‚Äôs own archivist (the official responsible for formally recognizing new constitutional amendments) rejected it, as did the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals. Thankfully, Texas has taken a first and important step toward eliminating the ABA‚Äôs undue and unwarranted influence on legal education and the legal community more broadly. Stay tuned, because there‚Äôs likely more to come from other states and the federal government. Please log in again. The login page will open in a new tab. After logging in you can close it and return to this page. We use cookies on our website. By using our website, you consent to cookies. Learn More .
articles.rewritten_text: Texas's Supreme Court has eliminated the requirement for law school graduates to attend American Bar Association-accredited schools before taking the state bar exam. The landmark decision, effective 2026, ends ABA's century-long accreditation monopoly amid criticism of its diversity policies and partisan positions.

articles.title: FOX Sports to Air 2026 World Baseball Classic, Including March 17 Championship
articles.description: FOX Sports will be the exclusive home for all 47 games of the 2026 World Baseball Classic, including the Championship Game on March 17.
articles.content: We all remember the epic conclusion to the 2023 World Baseball Classic. Japan and the United States locked in an instant classic with the title on the line. Shohei Ohtani stared down fellow MLB super‚Ä¶ [+2333 chars]
articles.full_text: We all remember the epic conclusion to the 2023 World Baseball Classic. Japan and the United States locked in an instant classic with the title on the line. Shohei Ohtani stared down fellow MLB superstar ‚Äì and then-teammate ‚Äì Mike Trout with two outs. And now we're set for the 2026 World Baseball Classic, which will once again feature the world's best players representing their countries, throughout March 2026. FOX is set to air seven games, including three Pool B games featuring the United States team, two Quarterfinals games and the World Baseball Classic Championship Game on Tuesday, March 17 from Miami‚Äôs loanDepot Park. The remaining matchups will air across FS1, FS2, the FOX Sports app, FOX One and Tubi ‚Äì full schedule and designations to be announced at a later date. In addition, FOX Deportes will carry 28 tournament games in Spanish including all four Quarterfinals games, two Semifinals contests, and the Championship Game. The 2026 edition of the WBC will be the sixth iteration of the global baseball tournament that will feature 20 teams competing in four first round pools in Tokyo, Japan; San Juan, Puerto Rico; Houston, Texas; and Miami, Florida, starting on Wednesday, March 4 and Thursday, March 5, 2026. The 2023 Championship Game averaged 5.2 million viewers and peaked at 6.5 million when the game was decided in the bottom of the ninth with Ohtani and Trout, Angels teammates at the time, squaring off in one of the more memorable at-bats in recent baseball history. With FOX broadcasting Major League Baseball games since 1996, the World Baseball Classic will precede the network‚Äôs 30th season of MLB coverage. "The World Baseball Classic embodies everything we love about the game ‚Äì passion, pride and world-class talent," said FOX Sports Executive Vice President, Head of Programming and Scheduling Bill Wanger. "Following the tournament‚Äôs wide-spread excitement and unforgettable finish from 2023, we‚Äôre honored to once again deliver this premier global event to fans across the country."
articles.rewritten_text: FOX Sports will broadcast the 2026 World Baseball Classic, including seven key games featuring Team USA and the championship match on March 17 in Miami. The tournament will span 20 teams competing across venues in Tokyo, San Juan, Houston, and Miami starting March 4.

articles.title: Cody Johnson Makes Shock Cancelation Amid Sudden Health Crisis

articles.author: Leena Nasir
articles.content: Country singer Cody Johnson said Tuesday he has cancelled all remaining concerts this year after suffering a ruptured eardrum that requires immediate surgery.  Johnson said the procedure and recovery‚Ä¶ [+1352 chars]
articles.full_text: Country singer Cody Johnson said Tuesday he has cancelled all remaining concerts this year after suffering a ruptured eardrum that requires immediate surgery. Johnson said the procedure and recovery will sideline him for weeks, making it impossible to sing. (RELATED: Rush Announces Reunion Tour In Honor Of Neil Peart) ‚ÄúWhile battling a severe upper respiratory and sinus infection, I burst my ear drum,‚Äù he wrote on Instagram. ‚ÄúThe severity of the rupture means I must undergo immediate surgery.‚Äù A post shared by Cody Johnson (@codyjohnson) NASHVILLE, TENNESSEE ‚Äì JUNE 07: Cody Johnson performs onstage during the 2024 CMA Music festival at the Nissan Stadium on June 07, 2024 in Nashville, Tennessee. (Photo by Jason Kempin/Getty Images) ‚ÄúThe healing process will take many weeks, and it is not possible for me to sing during this time,‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúWithout the surgery my downtime could be months.‚Äù Johnson ended his message on a hopeful note, saying he‚Äôs praying for a full recovery so he can return to performing. A post shared by Cody Johnson (@codyjohnson) ‚ÄúI pray for full healing so I can get well and return to doing what I love,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúThank you COJO Nation for the love and support now, and always.‚Äù The singer told disappointed fans to expect updates about cancelled shows, adding, ‚ÄúPlease stay tuned for an email from your ticket providers for further details.‚Äù A post shared by Cody Johnson (@codyjohnson) Johnson had six remaining 2025 shows on his ‚ÄúLeather Deluxe‚Äù tour, with stops planned in Pennsylvania, Alabama, Louisiana, Arizona and Nevada. Comments on his Instagram post were disabled, and he did not say when he expects to return to the stage.
articles.rewritten_text: Country star Cody Johnson has canceled his remaining 2025 concerts after suffering a ruptured eardrum during a severe respiratory infection. The singer requires immediate surgery and weeks of recovery, making performing impossible. The cancellations affect six shows across five states on his "Leather Deluxe" tour.

articles.title: Catherine Connolly says there is no 'recognition' of climate emergency in Budget 2026
articles.description: ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt expect any Budget to sort out those crises, but I do expect a Budget to be put in context of the existential threat posed by climate change.‚Äô
articles.author: Diarmuid Pepper
articles.content: PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE CATHERINE Connolly has criticised the Budget and said that the government has utterly failed to learn from the Covid pandemic and the declaration of a climate emergency.  She w‚Ä¶ [+3506 chars]
articles.full_text: PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE CATHERINE Connolly has criticised the Budget and said that the government has ‚Äúutterly failed to learn from the Covid pandemic and the declaration of a climate emergency‚Äù. She was speaking in the D√°il this evening in reaction to the Budget 2026 announcement in her role as an Independent TD. While she said the government has acknowledged ‚Äúthat the planet is burning‚Äù, she said there is no ‚Äúrecognition‚Äù of this in the Budget. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt expect any Budget to sort out those crises,‚Äù said Connolly, ‚Äúbut I do expect a Budget to be put in context of the existential threat posed by climate change.‚Äù She added that ‚Äúwe‚Äôre failing to recognise that we can‚Äôt continue with the same, unsustainable growth approach and do something about climate change‚Äù. She also said there were no provisions in relation to public health infrastructure so that ‚Äúwe would be prepared for the next pandemic‚Äù. Connolly also said she was ‚Äúworried‚Äù by a lack of a mention to homelessness. She also accused the government of ‚Äútwisting language‚Äù around housing. ‚ÄúIf you are in receipt of a HAP payment, you are not adequately housed in terms of social housing, and you‚Äôre twisting language on its head,‚Äù said Connolly. Connolly also said there was an ‚Äúutter failure to recognise that there‚Äôs an absolute crisis of a housing problem in the Gaeltacht‚Äù. She also said that the government had ‚Äúreneged on its solemn promise to do away with the means test for carers‚Äù. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know why we can go with economists telling us we have a growth economy when we‚Äôre not valuing the number of carers that are doing unpaid leave,‚Äù added Connolly. Advertisement She said the number of people providing regular unpaid care increased by over 50% between 2016 and 2022 to reach close to 300,000. Last week, Social Protection Minister Dara Calleary said that while the Government ‚Äúremains committed to phasing out the carer‚Äôs allowance means test‚Äù, it cannot be done ‚Äùin a single budget‚Äù and that it will be done in a ‚Äúprogressive manner‚Äù. Connolly also remarked that the government has ‚Äúfailed to train enough people to work in our hospitals‚Äù and that these are problems that ‚Äúcome up year after year‚Äù. ‚ÄúWe need to actually put out the message that they‚Äôre not inevitable,‚Äù said Connolly. Meanwhile, Connolly remarked that the ‚Ç¨11 million increase for schemes targeting violence against women is a ‚Äúdrop in the ocean‚Äù. ‚ÄúDespite our third strategy for zero violence against women, the figures keep rising, it‚Äôs an absolute crisis.‚Äù She also warned that many people are ‚Äúpaying two mortgages, one for a house and one for childcare‚Äù. She said the ‚Äúabsolute answer is public childcare because otherwise people can‚Äôt work‚Äù. Connolly is running for the √Åras against Fine Gael pick Heather Humphreys and speaking to LMFM this morning, Humphreys was asked about the government‚Äôs record on housing. She said there is a ‚Äúdisaster‚Äù in housing and that ‚Äúbillions and billions has been spent on housing and what we need to see are results‚Äù. Humphreys said that as president, she would not ‚Äúlet the country down‚Äù. She was also asked if she would ‚Äúspeak out against government policy‚Äù and replied that while the presidency is ‚Äúabove politics‚Äù, she ‚Äúcan speak out and there‚Äôs nobody better to speak out for people‚Äù. ‚ÄúAs I said, the presidency is above politics and I can assure you that if I see wrongdoings, if I see injustices, I will speak out. ‚ÄúI have never been afraid to speak out for people, and as president, that‚Äôs what I will do, I will be a voice for this nation.‚Äù Readers like you are keeping these stories free for everyone... articles.title: Lionel Messi loses key teammate for Argentina‚Äôs FIFA World Cup 2026 opener
articles.description: A key Argentina player will not be able to join Lionel Messi for the team‚Äôs debut at the FIFA World Cup 2026.  Just over eight months remain until the FIFA World Cup 2026 kicks off in the United States, Mexico, and Canada. Argentina will arrive looking to def‚Ä¶
articles.author: Alejandro Lopez Vega
articles.content: Just over eight months remain until the FIFA World Cup 2026 kicks off in the United States, Mexico, and Canada. Argentina will arrive looking to defend the title they won in Qatar 2022, and having Li‚Ä¶ [+3260 chars]
articles.full_text: By Alejandro Lopez Vega October 07, 2025 Just over eight months remain until the FIFA World Cup 2026 kicks off in the United States, Mexico, and Canada. Argentina will arrive looking to defend the title they won in Qatar 2022, and having Lionel Messi and the rest of the squad‚Äôs stars available will be crucial. However, one important player won‚Äôt be on the field for the opening match of the tournament. On Tuesday, FIFA published a list of players still serving suspensions from the September international break, and Nicolas Otamendi was among them. The Benfica defender was sent off during the World Cup qualifier against Ecuador and received a one-match suspension, along with a fine of 5,000 Swiss francs (around $6,300). With South America‚Äôs World Cup qualifiers having ended last month, Otamendi no longer has the opportunity to serve the suspension during that competition. Under these circumstances, the Argentine defender will have to wait for the next official FIFA tournament to serve the ban. Argentina‚Äôs calendar includes four friendlies between October and November, which will wrap up their 2025 schedule. In March, they have one more friendly and, very likely, the Finalissima against Spain. That match, although official, won‚Äôt count toward fulfilling the suspension, as it is not a FIFA-organized tournament but rather co-hosted by UEFA and CONMEBOL. Nicolas Otamendi of Argentina. All of this leads to a tough consequence for Argentina: Otamendi will have no choice but to serve his one-match ban in the opening game of the FIFA World Cup 2026 group stage. That‚Äôs in line with Article 9.2 of the FIFA regulations: ‚ÄúPending match suspensions imposed as a result of a direct or an indirect red card in matches in the preliminary competition of the FIFA World Cup 2026 will be carried over to the final competition.‚Äù see also Bad news for Lionel Messi: Argentina star misses US October tour due to injury Nicolas Otamendi‚Äôs situation also applies to another South American star. Chelsea‚Äôs Moises Caicedo was also sent off in the same match between Ecuador and Argentina and will therefore miss his team‚Äôs opening game at the 2026 World Cup ‚Äî a significant blow for Ecuador, considering the midfielder‚Äôs importance. Although rare, cases like these have occurred in previous tournaments. At the FIFA World Cup 2014 in Brazil, several players missed their teams‚Äô openers due to suspensions carried over from earlier matches that hadn‚Äôt yet been served. Freddy Guarin missed Colombia‚Äôs opener in that tournament against Greece, a game the South Americans won 3‚Äì0. The same happened with Mario Mandzukic, who was unavailable for Croatia‚Äôs World Cup opener against Brazil, a match they lost 3‚Äì1. Like Messi, Nicolas Otamendi announced back in September that he will not take part in the next World Cup cycle. That made the match against Ecuador his final appearance in South American qualifiers. Naturally, that also means the 2026 tournament in the United States, Mexico, and Canada will be the defender‚Äôs last major competition at international level. see also Argentina National Team TV Schedule Otamendi will close out a successful run with Argentina that began in 2009 and included three World Cup appearances (South Africa 2010, Russia 2018, and Qatar 2022). Over the last 16 years, the defender has collected four titles: the 2022 FIFA World Cup, the 2021 and 2024 Copa America tournaments, and the 2022 Finalissima.
articles.rewritten_text: Argentina defender Nicolas Otamendi will miss his team's 2026 World Cup opener due to a suspension from a red card in last month's qualifier against Ecuador. The ban carries over since South American qualifiers have ended, forcing the defending champions to start without their key defender.

articles.title: 6 Former Surgeons General Say RFK Jr. Is Endangering the Health of the Nation
articles.description: The bipartisan group of surgeons general included Democratic and Republican appointees dating back to the early 1990s.
articles.author: Truthout
articles.content: Honest, paywall-free news is rare. Please support our boldly independent journalism with a donation of any size.  Six former U.S. surgeons general have published an op-ed in The Washington Post, warn‚Ä¶ [+4492 chars]
articles.full_text: Honest, paywall-free news is rare. Please support our boldly independent journalism with a donation of any size. Six former U.S. surgeons general have published an op-ed in The Washington Post, warning Americans that Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is using his role as head of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to endanger the health of the nation. The authors of the op-ed, which was published on Monday, represent ‚Äúformer U.S. surgeons general appointed by every Republican and Democratic president since George H.W. Bush‚Äù ‚Äî including Jerome Adams, Richard Carmona, Joycelyn Elders, Vivek Murthy, Antonia Novello and David Satcher. The surgeons general said that they‚Äôve taken ‚Äútwo sacred oaths‚Äù in their lifetimes ‚Äî one as physicians and another as public servants. ‚ÄúIn keeping with those oaths, we are compelled to speak with one voice to say that the actions of Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. are endangering the health of the nation,‚Äù they wrote. Never miss the news and analysis you care about. ‚ÄúDespite differences in perspectives, we have always been united in an unwavering commitment to science and evidence-based public health. It is that shared principle that led us to this moment,‚Äù the authors went on, adding that Kennedy is a ‚Äúdriving force‚Äù behind a ‚Äúcrisis‚Äù of the department lacking scientific integrity and transparency. The former surgeons general said that Kennedy was unable to ‚Äúrestore trust‚Äù among the public when it comes to vital health initiatives, citing Kennedy‚Äôs long history of spreading lies about vaccines and his ‚Äúde-emphasis‚Äù of vaccination in the face of the worst measles outbreak in the U.S. over the past three decades. They also cited Kennedy‚Äôs recent (and discredited) claim that use of acetaminophen during pregnancy is linked to autism. That claim ‚Äúhas been widely condemned by the scientific and medical communities, who have pointed out that the available research is inconclusive and insufficient to justify such a warning,‚Äù they wrote. Rather than combating the rapid spread of health misinformation with facts and clarity, Kennedy is amplifying it. The consequences aren‚Äôt abstract. They are measured in lives lost, disease outbreaks and an erosion of public trust that will take years to rebuild. ‚ÄúSecretary Kennedy is entitled to his views. But he is not entitled to put people‚Äôs health at risk,‚Äù the former surgeons general wrote. ‚ÄúHe has rejected science, misled the public and compromised the health of Americans. The nation deserves a health and human services secretary who is committed to scientific integrity and can restore morale and trust in our public health agencies.‚Äù Kennedy has been widely condemned for his actions as head of HHS. Last month, 16 states plus Washington, D.C. sued HHS due to its threats to cut funding for sex ed classes if they included lessons on transgender people. HHS announced in August that it would no longer fund what it called ‚Äúgender ideology,‚Äù baselessly claiming that lessons that acknowledge the existence of trans people would ‚Äúpoison the minds of the next generation.‚Äù Other examples of Kennedy‚Äôs incompetence abound. In May, for example, HHS, under his leadership, released a ‚ÄúMake America Healthy Again‚Äù report that included multiple errant and fraudulent citations. A deeper examination of that report revealed that it was created in large part by using Artificial Intelligence (AI), a move that experts blasted as widely irresponsible due to the technology‚Äôs tendency to completely make up ‚Äúfacts.‚Äù And this past summer, Kennedy dismissed the entirety of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP), a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) board that issues guidance on vaccines and other methods to prevent infection. Kennedy filled most of the vacant spots on that board with anti-vaxxers and conspiracy theorists. According to a Quinnipiac University poll published in September, only 33 percent of Americans approve of the job Kennedy has done so far, while 54 percent disapprove. In the same survey, respondents were asked how confident they were in Kennedy‚Äôs medical advice. Only 39 percent said they had confidence in the information Kennedy cited, while 57 percent said they didn‚Äôt have much confidence in him. As we rise to meet the current wave of authoritarianism, Truthout appeals for your support. Independent media is a pillar of democracy and a powerful force for justice. Please make a tax-deductible one-time or monthly donation to Truthout if you can.
articles.rewritten_text: Six former U.S. surgeons general from both Republican and Democratic administrations published a Washington Post op-ed condemning Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s leadership. They accused him of endangering public health by spreading vaccine misinformation and undermining scientific integrity at the Department of Health and Human Services.

articles.title: ‚ÄòDoing nothing was a lot harder than I thought‚Äô: Gen Z is now ‚Äòrawdogging‚Äô boredom ‚Äî here‚Äôs why it‚Äôs good for them
articles.description: A self-styled productivity influencer has mastered the art of bore after sitting in silence every day for a month to fix his 'attention span.'
articles.author: Ben Cost
articles.content: This is putting a lot of effort into being lazy.  Generation Zers have devised a new way to mentally detox from omnipresent digital distractions ‚Äî by undertaking challenges where they do nothing all ‚Ä¶ [+4644 chars]
articles.full_text: This is putting a lot of effort into being lazy. Generation Zers have devised a new way to mentally detox from omnipresent digital distractions ‚Äî by undertaking challenges where they do nothing all day, as seen in TikTok clips with thousands of views. Dubbed rawdogging, the practice involves staring into space sans entertainment, sleep or other distractions to give themselves a respite in an age where everyone is glued to their screen. The craze initially took off this past summer aboard flights ‚Äî with Gen Z ascetics filming themselves undertaking sky-high psychological fasts ‚Äî but has since fanned out to other areas. In a recent series of videos, a self-proclaimed ‚Äúproductivity‚Äù influencer named Rowan conducted an experiment where he rawdogged for an hour each day to fix his ‚Äúattention span.‚Äù He explained that he‚Äôd been struggling with a ‚Äúshort attention span‚Äù due to ‚Äúconstant dopamine hits from my phone, caffeine, sugary foods and games.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis gave me such hard time to focus on my work and the things I really care about,‚Äù he explained, adding that he felt he needed to have his brain ‚Äúwander off freely without any stimulation.‚Äù It‚Äôs safe to say it was a lot of work for ‚Äúnothing.‚Äù In the first of the daily clips ‚Äî a 30-second timelapse filmed on Sept. 29, 2025 ‚Äî the content creator is seen sitting in a recliner fidgeting with his eyes closed at 120x speed. ‚ÄúJust sitting there doing nothing was a lot harder than I thought,‚Äù Rowan wrote. By day 7, the ascetic Jedi had mastered the art of ‚Äúbore,‚Äù explaining that he found boredom a lot more ‚Äúcomfortable.‚Äù He explained that he used to use his phone everywhere, including during showering, eating and on the toilet, but had recently not felt the need to ‚Äúcarry it everywhere.‚Äù The rawdogging marathon also paid major dividends on his output as well. ‚ÄúBecause I don‚Äôt need constant stimulation, I feel a lot more productive,‚Äù said Rowan. ‚ÄúI focus on the things that actually matter to me, like my work, relationships and being more present in the moment that matters instead of checking my phone every two seconds.‚Äù He added, ‚ÄúSo far I‚Äôm satisfied with the results.‚Äù Many viewers lauded Rowan‚Äôs rawdogging Odyssey with one fan calling the challenge ‚Äúgenuinely helpful‚Äù while another wrote, ‚Äúmotivating.‚Äù ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt even make it through watching you do this for 1 minute,‚Äù lamented one. However, others were less impressed. Recently, I have been struggling with having short attention span. Constant dopamine hits from my phone, caffeine, sugary foods and games. This gave me such hard time to focus on my work and the things I really care about. Then I came across a challenge for fixing your attention span. The premise for this challenge is for your brain to take a break and wander off freely without any stimulation. This is my first day of this challenge. I never tried this and it was challenging. Just sitting there doing nothing was a lot harder than I thought. I‚Äôm going to be doing this challenge for 30 days to show the difference. #dopaminedetox #100dayschallenge #focus #productivity #habitstacking ‚ÄúAnything but doing something productive,‚Äù said one detractor. Others accused Rowan of simply rebranding ‚Äúmeditation,‚Äù echoing criticism of Zoomers discovering things that already exist such as ‚Äúgirl dinners‚Äù (AKA leftovers). Coincidentally, many experts have espoused the virtues of being disinterested. ‚ÄúLearning how to tolerate boredom is an important skill,‚Äù Stacey Rosenfeld, PhD, a Rockland County psychologist, previously told the Post while speaking on the perks of being bored as a child. ‚ÄúThere are always going to be times when we‚Äôre bored. If we never allow ourselves to have that feeling of wondering ‚ÄòWhat should I do with this time,‚Äô how will we do that as adults?‚Äù In fact, some experts not only endorse boredom, they prescribe it. ‚ÄúDr. Carl Marci, a psychiatrist and author, claims that, after being bored for a while, his children will ‚Äústart to creatively solve their problems or distract themselves with social interaction or play,‚Äù allowing them to be curious and imaginative. Constant access to personal devices and screens ‚Äî which feature ‚Äúcontent designed primarily to capture a child‚Äôs attention and engage them as long as possible‚Äù ‚Äî teaches kids that ‚Äúthey don‚Äôt have to ever be bored,‚Äù he added. This isn‚Äôt just anecdotal, either. A study out of Texas A&M University found that boredom serves as a psychological signal to seek new experiences and grow as people.
articles.rewritten_text: Gen Z youth are embracing "rawdogging," a digital detox trend where they deliberately do nothing to combat screen addiction. The practice involves sitting quietly without entertainment or distractions. TikTok creator Rowan documented his experience, reporting improved focus and productivity after practicing daily hour-long sessions.

articles.author: Matthewgrobar
articles.content: EXCLUSIVE: Filmmaker Per Prinz has rounded out the cast of Coyote, a border thriller on which we were first to report, with four additions: Cheech Marin (Up in Smoke), Teresa Ruiz (Narcos: Mexico), D‚Ä¶ [+2259 chars]
articles.full_text: EXCLUSIVE: Filmmaker Per Prinz has rounded out the cast of Coyote, a border thriller on which we were first to report, with four additions: Cheech Marin (Up in Smoke), Teresa Ruiz (Narcos: Mexico), Dean Norris (Breaking Bad), and newcomer Katie Tripp. Described as a gritty, modern-day thriller exploring the dangerous underworld of border smuggling, the film‚Äôs lead is Esai Morales. Others in key roles include Mel Gibson and Renata Notni. The story follows Hern√°n Barroca (Morales), a weathered ex-smuggler pulled back into the dangerous world he thought he had left behind. When Hern√°n helps Julia and her young daughter, Maribel, navigate treacherous borderlands, their desperate journey triggers the wrath of a ruthless trafficking syndicate. As past and present collide ‚Äî with U.S. Border Patrol agent Jack Bradley (Gibson) joining the pursuit ‚Äî Hern√°n must rely on his cunning and grit to survive and find redemption. Marin plays Javier, a beacon of strength and light in a city controlled by the cartel, with Ruiz as Gabriella, a wise and resilient woman from Nogales who looks after those in need. Norris portrays the cunning and relentless Chief Dennison, with Tripp as Liz Bradley, a border patrol agent with a true-north moral compass, in her first major film role. Watch on Deadline Prinz wrote the script with Adam J. Goldstein. Scott Smith is producing for Fire Tiger Studios, along with Hamid and Camille Torabpour of Winter State Entertainment, and Morales and his Richport Entertainment. Breaking out in the ‚Äô70s as one half of the famed comedy duo Cheech & Chong, Marin has nearly 200 film and television credits, though he‚Äôs perhaps best known for roles in Tin Cup, Born in East L.A. and Up in Smoke, as well as the CBS police procedural Nash Bridges. Ruiz first garnered attention for her work in Netflix‚Äôs Narcos: Mexico before going on to projects like the Netflix series Mo and the film Father Stu opposite Mark Wahlberg. Best known for his role as DEA agent Hank Schrader on Breaking Bad, Norris can currently be seen starring alongside Christopher Meloni on Law & Order: Organized Crime. Other credits include Little Miss Sunshine, Carry On and TNT‚Äôs Claws, to name just a few. Norris is repped by Innovative Artists ‚Äî as are Marin and Ruiz. Marin is also repped by Weintraub Tobin Chediak; Ruiz by Hirsch Wallerstein Hayum; and Norris by Constellation Media Group. Tripp is repped by Marv Dauer Management and Abstract Talent Agency. Get our Breaking News Alerts and Keep your inbox happy. Comments On Deadline Hollywood are monitored. So don't go off topic, don't impersonate anyone, and don't get your facts wrong.
