articles.rewritten_text: Veteran actors Cheech Marin, Teresa Ruiz, Dean Norris and newcomer Katie Tripp join the cast of border thriller "Coyote," starring Esai Morales and Mel Gibson. The film follows an ex-smuggler drawn back into danger while helping a mother and daughter escape trafficking, with Gibson portraying a Border Patrol agent.

articles.title: Maria Steen calls for presidential election to be cancelled over Jim Gavin‚Äôs departure
articles.description: Conservative campaigner missed out on required signatures to make the ballot
articles.author: Ellen Coyne
articles.content: Maria Steen has called for the 2025 Irish presidential election to be cancelled and run again, claiming its political legitimacy has been further undermined by Fianna F√°il candidate Jim Gavin ending ‚Ä¶ [+2516 chars]
articles.full_text: Maria Steen has called for the 2025 Irish presidential election to be cancelled and run again, claiming its political legitimacy has been ‚Äúfurther undermined‚Äù by Fianna F√°il candidate Jim Gavin ending his campaign. Ms Steen, a conservative campaigner who had tried to run as an independent candidate, missed out on a place on the ballot paper after securing 18 of the required 20 signatures from TDs and senators before the deadline for nominations. Some of her supporters, who include social conservatives and other right-wing voters, have threatened to spoil their ballots on October 24th in protest at what they see as a lack of choice. Ms Steen‚Äôs failure to get enough support to run as a candidate also prompted criticism and online abuse of Independent TDs and Senators who declined to back her. Ms Steen says the dramatic exit of Mr Gavin from the race has ‚Äúfurther undermined‚Äù the upcoming poll. ‚ÄúDemocracy is supposed to mean that the people get to decide. The political legitimacy of the presidential election was already in doubt due to the closing of ranks by the major parties, which prevented any independent candidate from making it as far as the ballot,‚Äù Ms Steen said. ‚ÄúIt has now been further undermined by the dramatic implosion of the Fianna F√°il-backed candidacy of Jim Gavin. As a result, the public is left with very little choice, and a large constituency feels totally unrepresented. ‚ÄúGiven all that has happened, the better course at this stage would be to cancel the election and call a new one, if for no other reason than to secure public acceptance of the legitimacy of whoever is ultimately elected to serve as our next president.‚Äù Ms Steen said that if the presidential election was run again, it is ‚Äúlikely‚Äù that she would try to run again. [ A timeline of Jim Gavin‚Äôs short-lived push for the presidencyOpens in new window ] This month‚Äôs poll will now be the first presidential election in more than 50 years to only have two candidates actively contesting, though Mr Gavin will remain on the ballot paper. Canvassing in Louth on Tuesday, Fine Gael candidate Heather Humphreys said she was the ‚Äúcentre ground, common sense, pro-European candidate in this election‚Äù. ‚ÄúThe presidency is above party politics and I am asking voters to place their trust in me so that I can bring my experience to the role of president,‚Äù Ms Humphreys said. [ Michael McDowell: Why I didn‚Äôt nominate Maria Steen for the presidencyOpens in new window ] Independent candidate Catherine Connolly, still a TD, spent much of the day in the D√°il for the Budget. On Wednesday Ms Connolly will visit the offices of Alone, the older people‚Äôs organisation, to speak about issues relating to ageism and loneliness.
articles.rewritten_text: Conservative campaigner Maria Steen demands cancellation of Ireland's 2025 presidential election after Fianna F√°il candidate Jim Gavin's withdrawal. Steen, who failed to secure enough nominations to run, claims the election's legitimacy is compromised, leaving voters with limited choice between remaining candidates Heather Humphreys and Catherine Connolly.

articles.title: Victoria‚Äôs Secret Is Returning to ‚ÄúSexy.‚Äù You‚Äôre Not Going to Like Why.
articles.description: I hate to be the person who brings up Donald Trump in conversations about thongs, but ...
articles.author: Christina Cauterucci
articles.content: Sign up for the Slatest to get the most insightful analysis, criticism, and advice out there, delivered to your inbox daily.  After several years of emphasizing comfort, Victorias Secret is pivoting ‚Ä¶ [+12834 chars]
articles.full_text: Sign up for the Slatest to get the most insightful analysis, criticism, and advice out there, delivered to your inbox daily. After several years of emphasizing comfort, Victoria‚Äôs Secret is pivoting back to sexy. CEO Hillary Super, who took over last September, said in a recent interview with the Wall Street Journal that the underwear company had made a mistake by pulling back from the showy lingerie and suggestive advertising on which it made its name. Under Super‚Äôs direction, the brand has rolled out new additions to its ‚ÄúVery Sexy‚Äù collection, which features harness-inspired underwear, bejeweled ‚Äúmaximum lift‚Äù push-up bras that promise an increase of two cup sizes, and a thong with a tassel that dangles down one‚Äôs crack. The company is still presenting plenty of new comfort-driven basics and athleticwear, but it‚Äôs also adding lace teddies, costumes fit for a Halloween sex party, bras that quit before they reach the nipple, and a crotchless, cup-less leotard. (I use that term lightly.) On social media, the brand is pushing sheer lingerie, aggressive push-up bras, flouncy floral designs, and undergarments with blingy straps emblazoned with the company name. Victoria‚Äôs Secret is also leaning back into the glitzy flamboyance of its annual lingerie fashion show, which returned last year for the first time since 2018. I hate to be the person who always brings up Donald Trump in conversations about thongs, but it‚Äôs no coincidence that the end of Victoria‚Äôs Secret‚Äôs brief period of soft-touch sexuality has come at this precise moment. The past few years in fashion have heralded a return to both traditional femininity (ruffles, ballet flats) and shameless sexiness (clothing with cutouts), a two-pronged trend that has only accelerated during Trump 2.0. A partial referendum on the feminist triumphs and atmosphere of sexual caution of the #MeToo era, the new mode is also visible in the so-called Mar-a-Lago face adopted by women in the MAGA extended universe, which wears its garish makeup and medi-spa modifications as points of pride. Taut and filler-plumped, the Mar-a-Lago face somewhat resembles a push-up bra itself. Trump is concocting a world that rewards unabashedly manufactured caricatures of femininity. Who better to capitalize on the moment than a company that has, for generations, made the straight-faced argument that the sexiest thing in the world is a stiff, sculpted undergarment that hides our softest body parts behind a forbidding wall of foam? The original decision to dilute the raciness of the Victoria‚Äôs Secret brand, made by former head Martin Waters, came in 2019, when market research showed that its customers were looking for easy-wearing undergarments at low price points. Amid renewed scrutiny on Jeffrey Epstein‚Äîa close associate of former Victoria‚Äôs Secret CEO Les Wexner‚Äîand a 2020 New York Times expos√© on the sexism and sexual harassment suffered by employees and models, the company was battling a reputation for being ‚Äúinappropriate and off-color,‚Äù Waters told the Journal. In came a spate of products that seemed more fit for relaxation or exercise than brazen, sexually charged trysts, dovetailing with the rise of athleisure and the surge in demand for bralettes that came with the pandemic. Ad campaigns brought in models of varying body types and focused on the garments‚Äô comfort and value. The shift was an initial success, but eventually flopped. When Super took over from Waters last year, Victoria‚Äôs Secret was struggling, with sales on the downswing for more than two years. Having lost its hold on the mid-market American underwear drawer in a more crowded marketplace, it was ill-positioned to compete with new retailers like Kim Kardashian‚Äôs Skims, which sells sleek, neutral-toned basics, and other brands that offered a range of larger sizes. Both Super and Adam Selman, the executive creative director she tapped in the spring, have held top spots at Savage X Fenty, Rihanna‚Äôs affordable, size-inclusive lingerie brand. The new CEO says she is banking on a new interpretation of sexiness, one that appreciates a certain degree of comfort‚Äîa new bra boasts a more flexible underwire‚Äîand keeps the current body-positive outlook that was scorned by leaders of Wexner‚Äôs era. At the same time, she has tried to revive the hyperfeminine, male-gaze-oriented fantasy sold by Victoria‚Äôs Secret for decades before Waters restrained it. So far, it seems to be working: The company‚Äôs stock has risen almost 8 percent since Super took over, and in the most recent quarter, sales were up 3 percent over the same period last year, beating analysts‚Äô estimates. To the untrained eye, Victoria‚Äôs Secret‚Äôs new offerings don‚Äôt look much different from the old ones. In fact, the shift might be too subtle for casual consumers to clock on their own‚Äîmore about the brand‚Äôs photo-shoot vibes and product merchandising than any dramatic about-face in design. Perhaps customers will be wooed by the fantasy of looking like a seductive model wear
articles.rewritten_text: Victoria's Secret is reverting to its provocative roots under new CEO Hillary Super, who admits moving away from sexy lingerie was a mistake. The brand is expanding its "Very Sexy" collection with revealing designs and push-up bras, while reviving its signature fashion show after a five-year hiatus.

articles.title: ToothFairy 2.8.8
articles.description: ToothFairy 2.8.8 is a maintenance update of my Bluetooth menu bar utility. As annoying as Bluetooth is as a user, it‚Äôs even more so as developer. Seemingly straightforward APIs don‚Äôt work as advertised. I don‚Äôt just mean that they can fail with an error. They‚Ä¶
articles.author: Michael Tsai
articles.content: ToothFairy 2.8.8 is a maintenance update of my Bluetooth menu bar utility.  As annoying as Bluetooth is as a user, it‚Äôs even more so as developer. Seemingly straightforward APIs don‚Äôt work as adverti‚Ä¶ [+1000 chars]
articles.full_text: ToothFairy 2.8.8 is a maintenance update of my Bluetooth menu bar utility. As annoying as Bluetooth is as a user, it‚Äôs even more so as developer. Seemingly straightforward APIs don‚Äôt work as advertised. I don‚Äôt just mean that they can fail with an error. They can fail but say that they succeeded. They can succeed but say that they failed. Sometimes the synchronous API will work when the asynchronous one doesn‚Äôt or vice-versa. Sometimes the async API never calls back. With each major new macOS release, I hope it will fix some of this, but each seems to add its own new wrinkle that requires a workaround. With Tahoe, the issue is that IOBluetoothDeviceSelectorController sometimes doesn‚Äôt show devices even though they are paired with the Mac. They work and show up in System Settings but not in the Bluetooth chooser dialog to add them to a third-party app. This never seems to happen with AirPods, perhaps because their pairing is handled differently and syncs via iCloud, but it seems to be reasonably common with third-party headphones and input devices (and even Apple‚Äôs own Magic mouse/keyboard/trackpad). AirPods Bluetooth Mac Mac App macOS Tahoe 26 ToothFairy Blog Archives Tag Cloud Top Posts Recently Updated RSS Feed ¬∑ Comments Mastodon ¬∑ Twitter Apple News
articles.rewritten_text: A new update to ToothFairy, the Bluetooth menu bar utility for Mac, addresses issues with device detection in macOS Tahoe. While AirPods remain unaffected, third-party headphones and Apple peripherals sometimes fail to appear in Bluetooth selection dialogs despite being properly paired.

articles.title: Government slammed for lack of childcare measures after election promises
articles.description: Opposition and childcare services organisations said that measures outlined today will not make a dent when it comes to tackling systemic childcare issues.
articles.author: Eimer McAuley
articles.content: RIGHTS GROUPS AND childcare organisations have slammed the budget allocation for early learning and childcare today, as opposition politicians have called out the Government for failing to live up to‚Ä¶ [+6181 chars]
articles.full_text: RIGHTS GROUPS AND childcare organisations have slammed the budget allocation for early learning and childcare today, as opposition politicians have called out the Government for failing to live up to its election-time promises on capping childcare costs. Minister for Children Norma Foley said that the Government is making an ‚Äúunprecedented‚Äù investment in disability services and in children. The headline figures sound good: ‚Ç¨3.8 billion has been secured for the delivery of disability services alongside the HSE, which we are also told is ‚Äúunprecedented‚Äù, and ‚Ç¨1.48 billion for early learning and childcare, which the Department of Children says will ‚Äúreduce costs for families and increase supports for staff and providers‚Äù. However, there was no mention from the Minister or her colleagues today of the promise that both government parties made during the 2024 election that childcare costs would be capped at ‚Ç¨200 per month for parents across the country. While there is no specific package on childcare costs in the budget, funding increased by 9%, which equates to an increase of ‚Ç¨125 million. Foley today outlined that this funding increase will allow for over 286,000 children to benefit from the National Childcare Scheme, and for over 105,000 children to benefit from the Early Childhood Care programme. She also said that this will allow for 2,300 additional childcare places through the Government‚Äôs Core Funding Scheme. However, as Foley was outlining these measures, statements were coming in from organisations that represent childcare providers and rights‚Äô groups that universally said that this budget was a missed opportunity to tackle systemic childcare issues, barriers to access, and spiralling waitlists. The National Women‚Äôs Council (NWC) pointed out that the planned increase in places for the rest of this year and 2026 will do little to address the list of over 50,000 children waiting on a place. Doireann Crosson, Head of Policy for the NWC said that she welcomes the overall focus on childcare in this budget, but added that it‚Äôs ‚Äúdisappointing‚Äù that the places promised will be offered through existing schemes ‚Äúwhich continue to rely on private and often for-profit providers‚Äù. Early Childhood Ireland, another representative organisation for providers, said that ‚Äúthis approach will not address the systemic issues in our childcare system,‚Äù and that the additional places will ‚Äúbarely make a dent‚Äù. It was widely reported that Foley was pushing for a childcare costs package in this budget ‚Äì and while her department has an overall funding increase, it falls short of putting money back in parents‚Äô pockets or taking any major action to address the shortage of childcare places across the country. When asked by The Journal if she is disappointed that those kinds of measures aren‚Äôt provided for, and if she thinks voters who were swayed by the promise of childcare at ‚Ç¨200 a month, Foley insisted that childcare costs will be brought down ‚Äúover the lifetime of the Government‚Äù. Minister for Children Norma Foley acknowledges that childcare costs are still too high for many parents, and says that this budget will see a maximum fee cap in place for next Sept. No mention of the election promise of capping childcare costs at ‚Ç¨200 per month. @thejournal_ie pic.twitter.com/YtsgLgK274‚Äî Eimer McAuley (@eimer_mcauley) October 7, 2025 Minister for Children Norma Foley acknowledges that childcare costs are still too high for many parents, and says that this budget will see a maximum fee cap in place for next Sept. No mention of the election promise of capping childcare costs at ‚Ç¨200 per month. @thejournal_ie pic.twitter.com/YtsgLgK274 Advertisement In what is generally being perceived as the most austere budget in years, it seems that Foley is amongst several Ministers who had to settle for less than they would have hoped for. Foley was pressed for a response to the reaction from various groups today. In response to the comments made by the NWC, she said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always been very clear that there are three elements to ensuring that we are accessible in this sphere, one is that we would have accessibility, two, that we reduce the costs for parents, and three, that we have staff in place who are fully trained and happy to work in the sector. ‚ÄúLooking forward to 2026, this is the first budget of five that will begin supporting each of those three elements, to deliver better opportunity for children, and also parents,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been very clear that this is a commitment of our Government over the next five years‚Ä¶ we know that there are 73,000 places that are unused because we don‚Äôt have the staff,‚Äù she said. Foley pointed to the measures she has secured in this budget to get workers and providers onside with Government schemes. These include the continued rollout of the Core Funding Scheme. ‚ÄúCore Funding will also support improved pay for educators and school-age childcare practitioners with the implementation of the 2025 Employment Regu

Rights groups say the 9% funding increase won't address the 50,000-child waitlist or systemic issues in childcare access.

articles.title: 'Is Pam Bondi Married?' Trends on Google Search as Attorney General Faces Congress Today
articles.description: While US Attorney General Pam Bondi faced senators over the Epstein files, Google searches about her personal life exploded. Here's what happened in the tense hearing.
articles.author: Luis Vincent Gochoco
articles.content: Attorney General Pam Bondi faced a contentious hearing on Tuesday, fielding sharp questions from senators regarding the Justice Department's handling of the Jeffrey Epstein files. The high-stakes tes‚Ä¶ [+3074 chars]
articles.full_text: Attorney General Pam Bondi faced a contentious hearing on Tuesday, fielding sharp questions from senators regarding the Justice Department's handling of the Jeffrey Epstein files. The high-stakes testimony, covered live by outlets like the BBC, placed her at the centre of intense political scrutiny amid a deeply polarised environment. The session was closely watched by political analysts and the public. Nevertheless, as the serious proceedings unfolded, a far different conversation gained traction online. Public curiosity shifted from policy toward her personal life, with the question 'Is Pam Bondi married?' providing a peculiar backdrop to the day's events. Inside the hearing room, senators from both parties engaged in rigorous questioning. The discussions centred on the Justice Department's handling of the recently released Jeffrey Epstein files, a topic that has generated significant public interest. Lawmakers demanded greater transparency on why certain names were redacted, pushing Ms Bondi on the department's process. According to Newsweek, the exchanges between Bondi and committee members were often sharp and confrontational, reflecting a broader public demand for accountability. Furthermore, lawmakers pressed Ms Bondi on her past statements regarding former FBI Director James Comey, which some critics have described as contradictory to her current positions. Axios reported that this line of questioning aimed to scrutinise the consistency of her leadership at the department. The hearing underscored the deep divisions and politically sensitive nature of the topics at hand. Throughout the hours-long testimony, Ms Bondi defended her department's actions with prepared and firm responses, arguing that all protocols were followed correctly. AG Pam Bondi: "No one is above the law, that‚Äôs a quote from you, Senator Blumenthal." pic.twitter.com/WtTWAp30gX Despite the gravity of the proceedings, recent search interest in Ms Bondi's marital status began climbing shortly after the hearing commenced. The query 'Is Pam Bondi married?' quickly became a top trending topic related to her name. This phenomenon, often amplified by social media algorithms, highlights a common pattern where the personal lives of public figures become a focal point during moments of intense professional pressure. Such trends can sometimes overshadow the substantive policy debates at hand. This shift in focus reveals a disconnect between the critical issues debated in Washington and the topics that capture the public's immediate attention. While officials debated matters of national importance, many people were more interested in the attorney general's biography. For the record, public records indicate Pam Bondi has been married and divorced twice and is currently unmarried. This information, however, remained secondary to the significant policy implications of her testimony. The hearing concluded late in the afternoon, leaving questions about the long-term political fallout and her department's future decisions lingering in the capital. For more breaking news and analysis from the UK and around the world, follow IBTimes UK on social media and tune in daily. Join the conversation in the comments section below. Originally published on IBTimes UK
articles.rewritten_text: During a heated congressional hearing Tuesday, Attorney General Pam Bondi faced intense questioning about the Justice Department's handling of Jeffrey Epstein files. While she defended department protocols, public attention oddly shifted online, with searches about her marital status trending alongside the serious proceedings.

articles.title: Canadian Snowbirds will replace U.S. Navy as top draw in San Francisco airshow
articles.description: U.S. government shutdown has grounded Navy aerobatics team, but nine-member Snowbirds squadron can still perform.
articles.author: Chris Knight
articles.content: The U.S. Navys Blue Angels are traditionally the centrepiece of San Franciscos annual Fleet Week six F/A-18E Super Hornet fighter jets performing aerobatic manoeuvres in tight formation, to the delig‚Ä¶ [+4542 chars]
articles.full_text: The U.S. Navy‚Äôs Blue Angels are traditionally the centrepiece of San Francisco‚Äôs annual Fleet Week ‚Äî six F/A-18E Super Hornet fighter jets performing aerobatic manoeuvres in tight formation, to the delight of crowds. This year, the U.S. government shutdown has grounded those navy flyers along with a host of other military craft. The navy said in a statement to media this week that, unless the shutdown is quickly quashed, military personnel will not be able to participate in the event. Meanwhile, the show must go on, and so America‚Äôs allies to the north will step in. Get a dash of perspective along with the trending news of the day in a very readable format. By signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc. A welcome email is on its way. If you don't see it, please check your junk folder. The next issue of NP Posted will soon be in your inbox. We encountered an issue signing you up. Please try again Interested in more newsletters? Browse here. The Snowbirds, red-and-white Tutor trainer jets familiar to Canadians from their appearances at Toronto‚Äôs CNE airshow and other events across the country, will have pride of place in the Fleet Week show this coming weekend. Fleet Week has taken place annually over the Columbus Day Weekend since 1981. The only year that saw the event cancelled was 2013, when a 16-day U.S. government shutdown overlapped with the event. This time, organizers decided to keep going with a reduced set of performances and fly-bys. (The Blue Angels told the San Francisco Chronicle that their appearance is ‚Äúpaused‚Äù rather than ‚Äúcancelled,‚Äù in the hopes that the government may be up and running again by Friday.) This will be the second time in a month that the Royal Canadian Air Force has saved America‚Äôs bacon. Last weekend‚Äôs Pacific Airshow in Huntington Beach, Calif., had to go on minus the U.S. Air Force Thunderbirds teams thanks to the shutdown. But the nine-strong Snowbirds team stepped up as the headliners of the show, alongside some Royal Air Force planes and parachutists from the U.K., and a number of non-military teams and pilots not affected by the shutdown. ‚ÄúThank God Canada is not the 51st state yet,‚Äù Kevin Elliott, director of the show, told the New York Times, presumably in jest. He added that the organizers had been scrambling to rearrange the lineup around the sudden no-shows, but was relieved that the Snowbirds could ‚Äúshow up and, in a sense, save the day.‚Äù The Blue Angels are scheduled to appear in at least three more airshows over the next month: one in Georgia on the weekend of Oct. 17; and two in Florida on Oct. 25-26 and Nov. 1-2. There are no plans for the Snowbirds to fly in any of those shows. National Post has contacted the team for comment. The U.S. government shut down on Oct. 1. The longest shutdown in the nation‚Äôs history is 35 days, and began in 2018 during Donald Trump‚Äôs first presidency. articles.title: Today‚Äôs AI hype has echoes of a devastating technology boom and bust 100 years ago
articles.description: AI is showing some of the hallmarks of another technology‚Äôs rapid rise and fall back in the 1920s. These are the lessons we could learn.
articles.author: Cameron Shackell, Sessional Academic, School of Information Systems, Queensland University of Technology
articles.content: A crowd gathers outside the New York Stock Exchange following the 'Great Crash' of October 1929. New York World-Telegram and the Sun Newspaper Photograph Collection, US Library of Congress  The elect‚Ä¶ [+6446 chars]
articles.full_text: Sessional Academic, School of Information Systems, Queensland University of Technology Cameron Shackell works primarily as a Sessional Academic at the QUT School of Information Systems. He also works one day a week as CEO of Equate IT Consulting, a firm using AI to analyse brands and trademarks. Queensland University of Technology provides funding as a member of The Conversation AU. The Conversation UK receives funding from these organisations View the full list https://doi.org/10.64628/AA.usav94mnn The electrification boom of the 1920s set the United States up for a century of industrial dominance and powered a global economic revolution. But before electricity faded from a red-hot tech sector into invisible infrastructure, the world went through profound social change, a speculative bubble, a stock market crash, mass unemployment and a decade of global turmoil. Understanding this history matters now. Artificial intelligence (AI) is a similar general purpose technology and looks set to reshape every aspect of the economy. But it‚Äôs already showing some of the hallmarks of electricity‚Äôs rise, peak and bust in the decade known as the Roaring Twenties. The reckoning that followed could be about to repeat. A century ago, when people at the New York Stock Exchange talked about the latest ‚Äúhigh tech‚Äù investments, they were talking about electricity. Investors poured money into suppliers such as Electric Bond & Share and Commonwealth Edison, as well as companies using electricity in new ways, such as General Electric (for appliances), AT&T (telecommunications) and RCA (radio). It wasn‚Äôt a hard sell. Electricity brought modern movies, new magazines from faster printing presses, and evenings by the radio. It was also an obvious economic game changer, promising automation, higher productivity, and a future full of leisure and consumption. In 1920, even Soviet revolutionary leader Vladimir Lenin declared: ‚ÄúCommunism is Soviet power plus the electrification of the whole country.‚Äù Today, a similar global urgency grips both communist and capitalist countries about AI, not least because of military applications. Like AI stocks now, electricity stocks ‚Äúbecame favorites in the boom even though their fundamentals were difficult to assess‚Äù. Market power was concentrated. Big players used complex holding structures to dodge rules and sell shares in basically the same companies to the public under different names. US finance professor Harold Bierman, who argued that attempts to regulate overpriced utility stocks were a direct trigger for the crash, estimated that utilities made up 18% of the New York Stock Exchange in September 1929. Within electricity supply, 80% of the market was owned by just a handful of holding firms. But that‚Äôs just the utilities. As today with AI, there was a much larger ecosystem. Almost every 1920s ‚Äúmegacap‚Äù (the largest companies at the time) owed something to electrification. General Motors, for example, had overtaken Ford using new electric production techniques. Essentially, electricity became the backdrop to the market in the same way AI is doing, as businesses work to become ‚ÄúAI-enabled‚Äù. No wonder that today tech giants command over a third of the S&P 500 index and nearly three-quarters of the NASDAQ. Transformative technology drives not only economic growth, but also extreme market concentration. In 1929, to reflect the new sector‚Äôs importance, Dow Jones launched the last of its three great stock averages: the electricity-heavy Dow Jones Utilities Average. The Dow Jones Utilities Average went as high as 144 in 1929. But by 1934, it had collapsed to just 17. No single cause explains the New York Stock Exchange‚Äôs unprecedented ‚ÄúGreat Crash‚Äù, which began on October 24 1929 and preceded the worldwide Great Depression. That crash triggered a banking crisis, credit collapse, business failures, and a drastic fall in production. Unemployment soared from just 3% to 25% of US workers by 1933 and stayed in double figures until the US entered the second world war in 1941. The ripple effects were global, with most countries seeing a rise in unemployment, especially in countries reliant on international trade, such as Chile, Australia and Canada, as well as Germany. The promised age of shorter hours and electric leisure turned into soup kitchens and bread lines. The collapse exposed fraud and excess. Electricity entrepreneur Samuel Insull, once Thomas Edison‚Äôs prot√©g√© and builder of Chicago‚Äôs Commonwealth Edison, was at one point worth US$150 million ‚Äì an even more staggering amount at the time. But after Insull‚Äôs empire went bankrupt in 1932, he was indicted for embezzlement and larceny. He fled overseas, was brought back, and eventually acquitted ‚Äì but 600,000 shareholders and 500,000 bondholders lost everything. However, to some Insull seemed less a criminal mastermind than a scapegoat for a system whose flaws ran far deeper. Reforms unthinkable during the boom years followed. The Public Utility Holding C
articles.rewritten_text: The artificial intelligence boom mirrors the 1920s electricity revolution, which transformed the US economy before leading to market speculation and crash. Like today's AI stocks, electricity companies dominated markets through complex structures, with utilities comprising 18% of NYSE listings before the 1929 crash.

articles.title: The world‚Äôs most sensitive computer code is vulnerable to attack. A new encryption method can help
articles.description: End-to-end encryption is the gold standard to protect data ‚Äì and now it can be used beyond messaging platforms such as Signal.
articles.author: Qiang Tang, Associate Professor, Computer Science, University of Sydney, Moti Yung, Adjunct Research Professor, Computer Science, Columbia University, Yanan Li, PhD Candidate, School of Computer Science, University of Sydney
articles.content: Joan Gammell/Unsplash  Nowadays data breaches aren‚Äôt rare shocks ‚Äì they‚Äôre a weekly drumbeat. From leaked customer records to stolen source code, our digital lives keep spilling into the open.   Git ‚Ä¶ [+4926 chars]
articles.full_text: Associate Professor, Computer Science, University of Sydney Adjunct Research Professor, Computer Science, Columbia University PhD Candidate, School of Computer Science, University of Sydney Qiang Tang receives funding from Google via Digital Future Initiative to support the research on this project. Moti Yung works for Google as a distinguished research scientist. Yanan Li is supported by the funding from Google via Digital Future Initiative for doing this research at the University of Sydney. University of Sydney provides funding as a member of The Conversation AU. The Conversation UK receives funding from these organisations View the full list https://doi.org/10.64628/AA.rpm7duptf Nowadays data breaches aren‚Äôt rare shocks ‚Äì they‚Äôre a weekly drumbeat. From leaked customer records to stolen source code, our digital lives keep spilling into the open. Git services are especially vulnerable to cybersecurity threats. These are online hosting platforms that are widely used in the IT industry to collaboratively develop software, and are home to most of the world‚Äôs computer code. Just last week, hackers reportedly stole about 570 gigabytes of data from a git service called GitLab. The stolen data was associated with major companies such as IBM and Siemens, as well as United States government organisations. In December 2022, hackers stole source code from IT company Okta which was stored in repositories on GitHub. Cyberattackers can also quietly insert malicious code into existing projects without a developer‚Äôs knowledge. These so-called ‚Äúsoftware supply-chain‚Äù attacks have turned development tools and update channels on git services into high-value targets. As we explain in a new conference paper, our team has developed a new way to make git services more secure, with very little impact on performance. We already know how to keep conversations private: secure messenger services such as Signal and WhatsApp use end-to-end encryption, which locks messages on your device and only unlocks them on the recipient‚Äôs device. This protects the data even if the service platform is hacked, which is why it‚Äôs considered the gold standard to protect data. But git services, which are widely used by major tech companies and startups, currently don‚Äôt use end-to-end encryption. The same is true for most of the other tools we use to work together, such as shared documents. Because git services allow a huge number of collaborators to work on the same project at the same time, the software codes they host are constantly written and updated at a very rapid rate. This makes using standard encryption impractical. To do so would take up too much bandwidth to transmit all of the data for even one word change, and make the services very inefficient. But our new encryption method overcomes this challenge. The method we have developed uses what‚Äôs known as ‚Äúcharacter-level encryption‚Äù. This means only edits to a software code stored on the git service are treated as new data to be encrypted ‚Äì rather than the entire code. Think of it as encrypting the tracked changes in a word document, instead of a new version every time. This method strikes an important balance. It keeps the updated code private and secure while reducing the amount of communication between user and git services, as well as the amount of storage required. Importantly, this new method is also compatible with existing git services, making it easy for people to adopt. It also doesn‚Äôt interfere with other functions of git servers, such as hosting, saving bandwidth and indexing, so people can keep using these servers as they normally would ‚Äì just with the added benefit of extra security. This new tool is currently free and open-source for all users. It can be installed easily like a patch when using git services, and will run in the background as users access git services just like before. But this is just the starting point for a broader shift towards online collaboration that is secured by end-to-end encryption. Extending the same guarantees to shared documents, spreadsheets and design files is possible, but will require sustained research and investment. One complication to ensure security is managing encryption keys or credentials for users to decrypt encrypted data. Fortunately, our previous research shows us how to create a secure cloud storage system that will allow users to safely store their credentials. Just as importantly, we must balance security with compliance and accountability. Universities, hospitals and government agencies are required to retain and, in some cases, provide lawful access to certain data. Meeting these obligations, without weakening end-to-end encryption, pushes us to research new techniques. The goal is not secrecy at all costs, but verifiable controls that respect both privacy and the rule of law. We don‚Äôt need a brand new internet to get there. We need pragmatic upgrades that fit the tools people already use ‚Äì paired with clear, provable guarantees
articles.rewritten_text: A breakthrough encryption method could protect vulnerable git services, which host critical software code, from cyberattacks. The new "character-level encryption" system, developed by researchers, secures code repositories without compromising performance, addressing recent data breaches affecting major companies like IBM and government organizations.

articles.title: EXCLUSIVE CLIP: Rauw Alejandro Surprises a Classroom with Salsa Lesson on 'Celebrity Substitute'
articles.description: In the upcoming episode of YouTube's hit series Celebrity Substitute, Rauw Alejandro trades his tour wardrobe for a trench coat and glasses, stepping in as a disguised substitute teacher to deliver a surprise lesson in salsa music and dance.
articles.author: Alicia Civita
articles.content: You have known Rauw Alejandro, Raulito, Ra√∫l, El Zorro, but have you ever heard of Rauw Alejandro el maestro? Of course not, but you will in the upcoming episode of YouTube's hit series Celebrity Sub‚Ä¶ [+3176 chars]
articles.full_text: You have known Rauw Alejandro, Raulito, Ra√∫l, El Zorro, but have you ever heard of Rauw Alejandro el maestro? Of course not, but you will in the upcoming episode of YouTube's hit series Celebrity Substitute, in which the Latin superstar trades his tour wardrobe for a trench coat and glasses, stepping in as a disguised substitute teacher to deliver a surprise lesson in salsa music and dance. With a wink to his theatrical side, Rauw enters dressed like a 1970s detective and briefcase in hand. "What's up, class!" he says in a deadpan voice, before the room explodes in wave of shocked laughter and applause as students realize who's standing in front of them, as you can see in this exclusive clip for The Latin Times. He is there to teach about "the Caribbean and the Caribbean sound. Salsa, What is Salsa. They are going to learn what is salsa today," he explains as the describes dance and salsa dance in particular as "freedom." Of course, Rauw ends the lesson the only way he knows how: with a full-blown dance party, with Rauw's new song Mirando Al Cielo, as the soundtrack. The clip is part of Season 2 of Celebrity Substitute, which premiered September 10 and continues rolling out new episodes every other Wednesday through December. The show, hosted by Julian Shapiro-Barnum (Recess Therapy) and executive produced by EGOT (Emmy, Grammy, Oscar, Tony) winners Benj Pasek and Justin Paul (Ampersand), brings celebrities into real classrooms to surprise students with unexpected lessons on all kinds of topics, from music to literature and science to self-expression. Rauw's episode is set to debut on this Wednesday, October 8, joining a star-studded lineup that includes Ren√©e Rapp, Role Model, Gigi Hadid, Ed Sheeran, Malala Yousafzai, and more. Rauw Alejandro's surprise teaching moment comes on the heels of a major artistic and personal chapter. In late September, he released Cosa Nuestra: Cap√≠tulo 0, a conceptual album rooted in salsa, reggaet√≥n, and Afro-Caribbean rhythms, and a continuation of his 2024 record Cosa Nuestra. The project was praised for blending nostalgia with experimentation and for honoring Latin musical lineage. Just weeks earlier, Rauw was honored with the Hispanic Heritage Award for Vision, recognizing his impact on global Latin culture and his genre-expanding contributions to music. His Cosa Nuestra World Tour 2025 has drawn sold-out crowds across Latin America, the U.S., and Europe. In that context, his turn as a substitute teacher feels both playful and intentional. Produced in collaboration with Amazon, each Celebrity Substitute episode includes a moment where the company clears items from a featured teacher's Amazon Classroom List, a new tool designed to streamline how educators request materials and receive support. Viewers can directly contribute to real classrooms, transforming surprise celebrity moments into tangible resources for teachers and students. "Celebrity Substitute works because it pairs joy with generosity," said Julian Shapiro-Barnum. "Rauw brought heart, rhythm, and soul to his lesson, and the kids were all in." With his signature charisma, a salsa playlist, and a message of cultural pride, Rauw Alejandro reminds us that Latin music doesn't just fill stadiums, it inspires classrooms, too. articles.rewritten_text: Puerto Rican superstar Rauw Alejandro surprised students as a disguised substitute teacher in YouTube's "Celebrity Substitute" series. Dressed in a trench coat and glasses, he taught salsa music and dance, culminating in a classroom dance party. The episode debuts October 8 alongside appearances from Ed Sheeran and Gigi Hadid.

articles.title: State to provide ‚Ç¨9m for Ryder Cup preparations next year
articles.description: Funding to be allocated for bypass around Adare village, which will host golf competition in 2027
articles.author: Martin Wall
articles.content: The Government is to potentially provide 9 million next year towards hosting the Ryder Cup golf competition in Ireland.  Funding is also being targeted towards the long-planned bypass of the village ‚Ä¶ [+2677 chars]
articles.full_text: The Government is to potentially provide ‚Ç¨9 million next year towards hosting the Ryder Cup golf competition in Ireland. Funding is also being targeted towards the long-planned bypass of the village of Adare in Co Limerick, where the Ryder Cup is scheduled to be held in 2027. Minister of State at the Department of Communications, Culture and Sport Charlie McConalogue said there will be a significant increase in funding for major sporting events. He told The Irish Times there are a number of line items in the budget for such events, but the Ryder Cup is the most significant of these. ‚ÄúWe are very much looking forward to hosting (the event) in two years, and there is ‚Ç¨9 million projected at this point for the Ryder Cup," he said. ‚ÄúThe countdown to Ireland hosting the 2027 Ryder Cup and Euro 2028 is firmly on, and we will continue to invest in these and other major sports events in 2026. Ensuring that these events leave a lasting legacy for communities, drive economic growth, and impact positively on sports participation will continue to be a priority.‚Äù Separately, Minister for Public Expenditure Jack Chambers said funding will be provided for the Adare bypass road in Co Limerick. Funding for the Adare bypass was one of a number of projects announced as part of an overall ‚Ç¨19.1 billion investment in capital projects in Budget 2026. This represents an increase of ‚Ç¨2 billion on the 2025 figure. Mr Chambers said this allocation would provide the funding to progress ‚Äúthousands of new build social homes, major water infrastructure projects and flood relief schemes, build sustainability and resilience in our electricity grid, boost our electricity supply and major projects across the transport, health, education, justice, arts and sport sectors‚Äù. He said ‚Ç¨7.2 billion in capital funding would be allocated to housing. This includes ‚Ç¨2.9 billion to support the delivery of thousands of new build social homes and the second-hand acquisitions programme. It also incorporates ‚Ç¨1.2 billion for a starter homes programme, which aims to deliver thousands of starter homes through a range of supports alongside the Help to Buy initiative. The Minister said ‚Ç¨300 million will support the regeneration of towns and urban areas. The Government will give ‚Ç¨1.4 billion to Uisce √âireann to ‚Äúcontinue to build essential capacity to support new housing developments and to increase the resilience and sustainability of water supply‚Äù, he said. This will ‚Äúhelp to further progress development of waste treatment plants across the country‚Äù, he said. Some ‚Ç¨3.5 billion will be allocated to ESB and EirGrid to ‚Äústrengthen our energy security and accelerate our transition to renewable energy‚Äù, the Minister said. Capital funding for next year will also progress delivery of more than 300 school building projects, most of which are expected to be finished in 2026 and 2027, he said.
articles.rewritten_text: Ireland's government plans to allocate ‚Ç¨9 million for the 2027 Ryder Cup preparations, alongside funding for Adare village bypass in Limerick, where the tournament will be held. Minister Charlie McConalogue confirmed the investment, emphasizing the event's significance among upcoming major sporting events in Ireland.

articles.title: Lionel Messi breaks silence after Inter Miami‚Äôs Jordi Alba announces his professional retirement
articles.description: Following an extensive career, Jordi Alba announced his retirement from soccer at season's end with Inter Miami. Lionel Messi swiftly reacted to this, sharing a heartfelt comment on his post.   After joining Inter Miami in the 2023-24 season, Jordi Alba becam‚Ä¶
articles.author: Daniel Villar Pardo
articles.content: After joining Inter Miami in the 2023-24 season, Jordi Alba became a key player for the team. At 36 years old, he managed to remain the undisputed left back, despite competition from younger players.‚Ä¶ [+2623 chars]
articles.full_text: By Daniel Villar Pardo Updated on October 07, 2025 After joining Inter Miami in the 2023-24 season, Jordi Alba became a key player for the team. At 36 years old, he managed to remain the undisputed left back, despite competition from younger players. He has not only been a key part of the defensive line, but also a key part of the offense. Despite this, Jordi recently announced his retirement at the end of the season, prompting Lionel Messi to leave a heartfelt comment on his post. On his Instagram profile, Jordi Alba posted a video announcing his retirement at the end of the season with Inter Miami, with the caption ‚ÄúThank you soccer, thank you for so much.‚Äù Lionel Messi was quick to react, ‚ÄúThank you, Jordi. I‚Äôm going to miss you a lot. After so many things together, it‚Äôs going to be strange to look to my left and not see you there‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs crazy how many assists you gave me over all these years‚Ä¶ Who‚Äôs going to give me the back passes now???‚Äù. Throughout his career, Jordi Alba has established himself as one of Lionel Messi‚Äôs most effective partners, with the duo contributing to an impressive 48 goals together. Their connection transcended mere statistics, however, as their intuitive on-field understanding consistently generated scoring opportunities in every match. This synergy undoubtedly ranks him among the most formidable teammates in Messi‚Äôs career. Jordi Alba has cemented his legacy at Inter Miami since joining as a veteran presence. Over 95 appearances, the Spanish full-back has tallied 14 goals and 28 assists, showcasing his extraordinary influence on the pitch. As the Herons advance in the 2025 MLS Playoffs, Alba‚Äôs contributions could help steer them toward their first-ever MLS Cup triumph, marking a milestone in franchise history. Jordi Alba of Spain poses for a photograph with the UEFA Nations League trophy. Over an illustrious 18-year career, Jordi Alba has carved out a legacy as one of the premier left-backs in Spanish soccer. Initially beginning his career as a left winger, he found his true calling at Valencia CF, where his transformation into a left-back drew the attention of FC Barcelona. In 2012, the Catalan giants‚Äîwhere Alba had trained as a youth‚Äîbrought him back to the fold, cementing his status as one of the most significant players in their storied history. see also How many trophies has Jordi Alba won? Complete trophy list with Barcelona, Inter Miami, and Spain Upon joining Barcelona, Alba swiftly cemented his status as one of Lionel Messi‚Äôs most reliable teammates. His consistent performances earned him a permanent spot in the starting lineup for over a decade. During his decorated tenure, he clinched 20 major titles with both Barcelona and the Spanish national team. Additionally, he played a pivotal role in securing Inter Miami‚Äôs first two championships, bringing his professional title count to 22.

The 36-year-old Spanish left-back, who joined Miami in 2023, formed a prolific partnership with Messi throughout their careers, contributing to 48 goals together.

articles.title: Telcos face surprise 'stress test' within weeks as Optus fallout continues
articles.description: The adequacy of Australia's emergency call network will be stress tested with a surprise drill ahead of bushfire season, as the opposition ramps up its assault over the communication minister's handling of last month's fatal triple-0 outage.
articles.author: Maani Truu and Isabella Tolhurst
articles.content: The adequacy of Australia's emergency call network will be stress tested with a surprise drill ahead of bushfire season, as the opposition ramps up its assault over the communication minister's handl‚Ä¶ [+6043 chars]
articles.full_text: Topic:Federal Government Anika Wells was hammered with questions about the government's response to the outage on Tuesday. (ABC News: Matt Roberts) Australia's telecommunications companies will be subject to a surprise outage simulation to test their triple-0 systems. The drill was agreed to during a meeting between the minister and the heads of Optus, TPG and Telstra, which coincided with the introduction of a bill to enshrine a so-called "Triple Zero Custodian" ‚Äî one of the key recommendations in a report handed down 18 months ago. A telecommunication expert believes such a custodian could go a long way to prevent extended outages like the recent Optus incident, which has been linked to a number of deaths. The adequacy of Australia's emergency call network will be stress tested with a surprise drill ahead of bushfire season, as the opposition ramps up its assault over the communication minister's handling of last month's fatal triple-0 outage. Communications Minister Anika Wells summoned the bosses of Australia's telecommunications companies to Parliament House on Tuesday, almost three weeks after a 13-hour Optus outage was linked to multiple deaths in South Australia and Western Australia. She emerged from the meeting with a list of priority actions aimed at bolstering the network against further disasters and an agreement from the telcos to submit to a simulated outage facilitated by the National Emergency Management Agency, which the government wants to see happen within weeks. Ms Wells said the drill would identify "where this system is not currently working for people", while she put the blame for the recent outages squarely on the Singaporean-owned telco. "The only thing that could have stopped Optus from having this outage was Optus themselves," she said in Question Time, as she withstood a barrage of questions about her response to the incident from the opposition benches. Details of how the test will function are still being worked out and Shadow Communications Minister Melissa McIntosh expressed surprise that such drills were not already occurring. Melissa McIntosh has called for an independent investigation into the incident as well as a public register of triple-0 outages. (ABC News: Matt Roberts) "You would think that telcos would be doing this anyway, that it would be a responsibility for them to be checking their systems," she said. "I don't know that it will particularly change things, and the expectation is already there that they do that." The meeting ‚Äî which the telco chiefs described as "constructive and important" in a joint statement afterwards ‚Äî coincided with the government's introduction of a bill to give a so-called "Triple Zero Custodian" powers to oversee the entirety of the system. A custodian was one of the key recommendations of the Bean Review, which was commissioned in the aftermath of an earlier Optus network outage that impacted 10 million customers and handed down 18 months ago, sparking questions over why it was not enshrined sooner. Shadow Communications Minister Melissa McIntosh said she only received a draft of the bill the night before it was introduced, describing the short time for review as "unusual". The Coalition agrees with the need to introduce a triple-0 custodian in principle, but support for the bill remains subject to partyroom approval. "Of course we support the intent of the legislation, we want to protect Australians ‚Ä¶ but the government has been sitting on the recommendations of the Bean Review for a year and a half," Ms McIntosh said. "And then all of a sudden they want to rush legislation through the parliament, so we have questions about their intent. "I would hate for the legislation just to be a bureaucratic answer ‚Ä¶ we want things to actually make a difference to the triple-0 network." The government accepted all 18 of the Bean recommendations when the report was handed down, but a year and a half later, Ms Wells said five were still yet to be fully implemented. Telecommunications experts have had mixed opinions on whether the recommendations, if they were in place, would have prevented the Optus outage, but associate professor Paul Gardner-Stephen from the Flinders College of Science and Engineering believes a Triple Zero Custodian "makes all the sense in the world". He argued that was because during the September outage, it appeared as if the failed calls had not been monitored by Optus and "that's exactly the kind of thing the Triple Zero Custodian, you imagine, would be monitoring and making public, in fact". Under that scenario, he said, the custodian could immediately raise the alarm, notify senior levels of the telco and instruct them to launch a critical incident response without the hours-long delay that occurred in reality. "It would be orders of magnitude faster; instead of it being 13 hours, I would have thought that within 13 minutes, under a triple-0 custodial regime, Optus would have been alerted," he said. "The balance of probab
articles.rewritten_text: Australian telecom companies will undergo surprise outage simulations to test triple-0 emergency systems following a recent Optus network failure linked to multiple deaths. Communications Minister Anika Wells announced the drills after meeting with major telco executives, alongside plans to establish a "Triple Zero Custodian" oversight role.

articles.title: Industry warns 'no gas, no future' amid high prices and falling demand
articles.description: A future made in Australia? Not if gas prices keep rising, major manufacturers warn as they call for urgent action to secure affordable supply.
articles.author: Rhiana Whitson
articles.content: Australia's biggest manufacturers have warned the nation's 'broken' east coast gas market could cost thousands of jobs and derail the government's Future Made in Australia policy.  In a speech to the‚Ä¶ [+8855 chars]
articles.full_text: Topic:Oil and Gas Mark Vasella says BlueScope Steel workers ‚Äî and Australia ‚Äî face industrial decline without a gas reservation policy. (ABC Illawarra: Tim Fernandez) In a speech to the National Press Club today, Mark Vassella will warn Australia is at risk of following the UK's industrial decline. He and other industry leaders say without cheaper gas, the federal government's Future Made in Australia policy is doomed. Mr Vassella's address will build pressure on the government as it reviews the gas market. Australia's biggest manufacturers have warned the nation's "broken" east coast gas market could cost thousands of jobs and derail the government's Future Made in Australia policy. In a speech to the National Press Club in Canberra today, BlueScope Steel chief executive Mark Vassella will warn Australia risks repeating the United Kingdom's industrial decline if the federal government fails to fix the gas market. He said the UK's experience ‚Äî driven by high energy costs and poor policy decisions ‚Äî should serve as a "cautionary tale" for Australia. "Australian manufacturing is at a dangerous crossroad," Mr Vassella said. Australian manufacturing is facing a worrying future, says Mr Vasella. (Supplied: GFG Alliance) "Major change is required to fix our broken gas market and reinstate a fair domestic price. "If we can't, we face a decline in manufacturing, similar to that which we've seen in the UK steel industry." Mr Vassella, a member of Manufacturing Australia, is urging the federal government to adopt an east coast gas reservation policy and a $10-a-gigajoule price cap to guarantee affordable supply for domestic manufacturers. The industry group says reserving even one-third of current east coast production would be enough to meet domestic manufacturing and residential needs, while still allowing most gas to be exported. It says immediately reserving uncontracted gas would bring rapid relief for east coast manufacturers struggling with soaring energy costs. Mark Vasella is taking his message to the National Press Club. (Kelly Fuller) "Despite our massive gas reserves, Australia has one of the highest wholesale gas prices among producer nations in the world," Mr Vassella said. "Worse, the adoption of a pricing mechanism that is based on LNG export prices means that local gas users are effectively paying for export infrastructure they don't use. "This is not right. It increases local gas prices and puts local gas users at a structural disadvantage." Mr Vassella also calls for new gas supply to be brought online quickly. Frustration in the sector is at boiling point after years of policy interventions that have failed to bring down prices. Mr Vassella's National Press Club address will heap pressure on the federal government, which is conducting a gas market review due later this year. Manufacturers argue that, despite gas demand across eastern Australia falling by about 20 per cent in a decade, they are still paying some of the highest prices in the world. Last year, the average price for wholesale gas in Australia was an average $10.30 a gigajoule, compared with $2.20 in Qatar and $3 in the United States. Manufacturing Australia ‚Äî which includes executives from major gas users such as BlueScope Steel ‚Äî says the federal government's $12-a-gigajoule wholesale gas cap has failed to deliver. "The intention was for that to be a cap ‚Äî it's not; it's effectively a floor," Manufacturing Australia chief executive Ben Eade told ABC News. Mr Eade said newer offers were typically more expensive. The slump in eastern Australia gas prices per gigajoule since 2023. (Supplied: Australian Energy Producers) Mr Eade said some manufacturers were facing contract offers of up to $20 a gigajoule. "It shouldn't be controversial to say that in a country like Australia ‚Äî which is awash with gas ‚Äî we should be able to supply domestic customers first, while still maintaining a thriving and globally significant export industry," he said. "This isn't a choice between the two, but for the past 10 or 15 years, we've effectively chosen the interests of exporters over those of domestic customers." The sector's frustration is backed by the ACCC's gas inquiry September interim report, which found recent federal interventions ‚Äî including the gas market code, the heads of agreement with LNG exporters and the domestic gas security mechanism ‚Äî had delivered "no material improvement" for major users. Gas demand in eastern Australia has been falling across most sectors for the past decade. (Supplied: IEEFA) The regulator also warned supply shortfalls could re-emerge by mid-2026 if uncontracted LNG continues to be shipped offshore. Joshua Runciman, lead analyst for Australian gas at the Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis (IEEFA), said east coast prices were high because the market was tightly linked to international LNG. "LNG prices have increased quite a lot in recent years. This is compounded by the domestic market not having e
articles.rewritten_text: BlueScope Steel CEO Mark Vassella warns Australia faces industrial decline without cheaper gas prices and a reservation policy. Speaking at the National Press Club, he urged the government to implement price caps and reserve east coast gas production to protect manufacturing jobs and domestic supply.

articles.title: California Bans Loud Streaming Commercials
articles.description: Netflix, Disney+ and the other major streamers will have to turn down the volume starting July 1, 2026, under new legislation signed into law by Gov. Gavin Newsom The post California Bans Loud Streaming Commercials appeared first on TheWrap.
articles.author: Lucas Manfredi
articles.content: Netflix, Disney+ and the other major streamers will have to dial down the volume on their commercials in California after Governor Gavin Newsom signed a law banning advertisements that are louder tha‚Ä¶ [+2627 chars]
articles.full_text: Netflix, Disney+ and the other major streamers will have to dial down the volume on their commercials in California after Governor Gavin Newsom signed a law banning advertisements that are louder than the main video content being watched. The move, which builds on Congress‚Äô Commercial Advertisement Loudness Mitigation (CALM) Act passed in 2010, would require streamers to comply with the volume limits starting July 1, 2026. ‚ÄúWe heard Californians loud and clear, and what‚Äôs clear is that they don‚Äôt want commercials at a volume any louder than the level at which they were previously enjoying a program,‚Äù Newsom said in a statement. The legislation comes after the Federal Communications Commission has received thousands of complaints in the past several years about loud commercials on broadcast, cable, and satellite television. In February, the FCC said the number took a ‚Äútroubling jump last year, which warrants a second look.‚Äù Senator Thomas Umberg, who is the author behind the legislation, said it was inspired by his legislative director, Zach Keller, who complained that loud streaming commercials were waking up his infant daughter, Samantha. ‚ÄúSB 576 brings some much-needed peace and quiet to California households by making sure streaming ads aren‚Äôt louder than the shows we actually want to watch,‚Äù Umberg added. Umberg‚Äôs bill initially faced opposition from The Motion Picture Association and Streaming Innovation Alliance, who represent the major entertainment conglomerates. ‚ÄúUnlike in the broadcasting cable network environment, where advertisers sell their ads directly to the networks, streaming ads come from several different sources and cannot necessarily or practically be controlled by streaming platforms,‚Äù MPA vice president of state government affairs, Melissa Patack said in testimony last year. ‚ÄúThe technology that encodes and inserts ads from advertisers and third party intermediaries into programming occurs in real time.‚Äù At the time, Patack noted that the Audio Engineering Society and the Interactive Advertising Bureau were already working address loudness issues and develop best practices to match the loudness of ads with programming. She added that many streaming services publish audio specifications to advertisers, ad networks and ad exchanges and request source coding from advertisers so that they can make ‚Äúreasonable efforts to normalize ad loudness.‚Äù The opposition was later dropped after Umberg amended the bill to add legal provisions that would protect streamers from lawsuits from private entities and leave enforcement to the state attorney general‚Äôs office. Representatives for the MPA, SIA, Paramount and Prime Video declined to comment. Netflix, Disney, Warner Bros. Discovery, Peacock and Apple TV+ did not immediately return TheWrap‚Äôs request for comment.
articles.rewritten_text: California Governor Gavin Newsom signed legislation requiring streaming services to match commercial volumes with regular programming by July 2026. The law, inspired by complaints about loud ads waking sleeping children, builds on the 2010 CALM Act and will be enforced by the state attorney general.

articles.title: Sora 2 Has a Huge Financial Problem
articles.description: 'People are generating much more than we expected per user, and a lot of videos are being generated for very small audiences.' The post Sora 2 Has a Huge Financial Problem appeared first on Futurism.
articles.author: Victor Tangermann
articles.content: It didn‚Äôt take long for OpenAI‚Äôs text-to-video-and-audio AI generator app, Sora 2, to melt down into a messy pile of potentially copyright-infringing AI slop.  Within just days, the TikTok-style app‚Äô‚Ä¶ [+4208 chars]
articles.full_text: It didn‚Äôt take long for OpenAI‚Äôs text-to-video-and-audio AI generator app, Sora 2, to melt down into a messy pile of potentially copyright-infringing AI slop. Within just days, the TikTok-style app‚Äôs mind-numbing feed of AI-generated content was filled with videos of Nickelodeon‚Äôs SpongeBob SquarePants cooking up blue crystals in a meth lab, entire episodes of South Park, and depictions of physicist Stephen Hawking being brutalized in horrible ways. The app‚Äôs prominent use of recognizable intellectual property and the likenesses of real people, combined with its sheer amount of hype, has allowed it to shoot up to the top of Apple‚Äôs App Store, with Meta‚Äôs competing Vibes app, which was released less than a week before Sora 2, quickly turning into a long-forgotten footnote in AI slop history. All that success creates a problem for OpenAI: how to stop Sora 2 from burning through cash as users generate countless resource-intensive AI videos. In an update posted to his personal blog, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman admitted that the company had a lot of work to do, especially when it comes to turning its AI slop generator into a moneymaker. ‚ÄúWe are going to have to somehow make money for video generation,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúPeople are generating much more than we expected per user, and a lot of videos are being generated for very small audiences.‚Äù It‚Äôs a pressing issue for the firm because of the sheer amount of computing power needed to generate AI videos. Last month, researchers from the open-source AI platform Hugging Face found that the energy demands of text-to-video generators quadruple when the length of videos doubles, suggesting the power required increases quadratically, not linearly. Multiply those demands by the number of videos being generated on Sora 2, and OpenAI is likely looking at massive compute demands. In other words, OpenAI‚Äôs foray into slop-based social media could quickly turn into a very costly endeavor. And turning Sora 2 into a source of revenue won‚Äôt be easy. It‚Äôs not clear that users will actually pay to use the service ‚Äî and adding to OpenAI‚Äôs woes, rightsholders could soon be asking questions about its eyebrow-raising ask-for-forgiveness-later approach to intellectual property and content moderation. The company has since slammed on the brakes, implementing guardrails on Sora 2 that were mysteriously absent on day one, as copyright lawyer Aaron Moss pointed out in a recent article. Users are running into the company‚Äôs content blocks at full force, resulting in widespread frustration. As Altman‚Äôs blog post indicates, the company doesn‚Äôt have a fleshed-out plan on how to generate revenue. Some of the proceeds, according to the CEO, will be shared ‚Äúwith rightsholders who want their characters generated by users.‚Äù But where those proceeds will come from ‚Äî presumably, either from advertising or users ‚Äî remains unclear. ‚ÄúThe idea ‚Äî perhaps similar to YouTube‚Äôs ad-monetization program for videos that include copyrighted material ‚Äî would give studios a financial incentive to opt in,‚Äù Moss wrote in his piece. ‚ÄúWhen thousands of GPU-intensive ten-second ‚ÄòSouth Park‚Äô clips also risk copyright lawsuits, the math gets ugly fast,‚Äù he added. But if ‚Äústudios become partners rather than adversaries, OpenAI can potentially offset costs while buying legal cover.‚Äù Wooing rightsholders to OpenAI‚Äôs side, especially now that the company has allowed for potentially copyright-infringing material to proliferate widely, is far easier said than done. Indeed, major rightsholders have already filed lawsuits against generative AI companies. Case in point, just last month, Warner Bros. Discovery sued AI text-to-image generator company Midjourney for infringement, joining Disney and NBC Universal. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a world of difference between studios collecting YouTube ad revenue on video clips they produce and control, and handing over their characters for anyone to freely manipulate in exchange for a few bucks,‚Äù Moss wrote. Other netizens pointed out that copyright holders may balk at OpenAI‚Äôs courting attempts. ‚ÄúWhy on earth would any brand pay for their IP to be surfaced by a user prompt upon their requests?‚Äù one argued. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not even close to how any of this works.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhy would I, as a multibillion-dollar rightsholder, not just take you to the cleaners?‚Äù another user added. More on Sora 2: OpenAI‚Äôs Sora 2 Already Melting Down Into Outrageous Drama
articles.rewritten_text: OpenAI's Sora 2 text-to-video app faces financial challenges as users generate excessive AI videos featuring copyrighted content. CEO Sam Altman acknowledges the high computing costs and need for monetization. The app's content includes unauthorized use of characters like SpongeBob and requires costly processing power.

articles.title: Scientists Prove That Human Gut Bacteria Can Survive a Trip to Space Without Us
articles.description: The findings have major implications for humanity's plans to explore Mars.
articles.author: Passant Rabie
articles.content: Space travel is not for the weak. Astronauts endure motion sickness, disorientation, cardiovascular stressand that‚Äôs before they even reach orbit. Luckily, the bacteria that lives inside us is far mo‚Ä¶ [+3248 chars]
articles.full_text: Space travel is not for the weak. Astronauts endure motion sickness, disorientation, cardiovascular stress√¢¬Ä¬îand that‚Äôs before they even reach orbit. Luckily, the bacteria that lives inside us is far more resilient. A new study shows that a gut bacteria essential for human health can survive the stress of being launched into space aboard a rocket, the microgravity environment, and reentry into Earth‚Äôs atmosphere. A group of scientists in Australia launched spores of Bacillus subtilis, a gram-positive bacteria that lives in our intestinal tracts, to the edge of space to see how the microbes fared. Upon examination after the bacteria had returned to Earth, the scientists found the microbes had experienced no change in their ability to grow and that their structure remained intact. The findings are detailed in a study published Monday in npj Microgravity. The work indicates that the bacteria would likely work as needed inside the guts of any humans on their way to Mars√¢¬Ä¬îcrucial information for astronaut health. But it also suggests that human-led contamination of Mars with Earthly bacteria may be inevitable. Previous experiments on board the International Space Station (ISS) have shown that certain types of bacteria can survive in space. There hasn‚Äôt been much research done, however, on the effects of a rocket launch and reentry on the survival rates of human gut bacteria. In order to put the bacteria to the test, the researchers packed spores on board a sounding rocket and launched it to an altitude of around 160 miles (260 kilometers) above the surface of Earth. During the second stage burn, the rocket experienced a maximum acceleration of 13 G (or 13 times the force of Earth‚Äôs gravity). Once it reached its desired altitude, the researchers initiated a brief period of weightlessness that lasted for around six minutes as the main engine shut off. After that, the rocket began its descent to Earth, decelerating at forces up to 30 G while spinning at a rate of 220 times per second. After the grueling journey, the researchers examined the bacteria spores to see how they fared during the rocket launch and reentry. Surprisingly, the bacteria showed no change to their structure, nor did the extreme forces affect its ability to grow. ‚ÄúOur research showed an important type of bacteria for our health can withstand rapid gravity changes, acceleration and deacceleration,√¢¬Ä¬ù Elena Ivanova, a professor at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology in Australia, and co-author of the study, said in a statement. ‚ÄúIt√¢¬Ä¬ôs broadened our understanding on the effects of long-term spaceflight on microorganisms that live in our bodies and keep us healthy. This means we can design better life support systems for astronauts to keep them healthy during long missions.‚Äù The idea of bacteria surviving and thriving on their way to the Red Planet, however, isn‚Äôt always met with enthusiasm. The findings follow a separate study published last year which warned bacteria not only have the potential to survive a trip to Mars, but also feel right at home in the Martian soil.√Ç As space agencies plan for human missions to Mars, there is growing concern that those missions could contaminate the Martian environment with out Earthly microbes. That could lead to mistaken discoveries of life on the planet, but it could also pose an immediate risk to the astronauts themselves√¢¬Ä¬îor indeed, any life that might be on Mars in the first place.
articles.rewritten_text: Australian scientists discovered that Bacillus subtilis, a vital gut bacteria, can survive extreme space conditions including rocket launch, microgravity, and reentry. The bacteria showed no structural changes after enduring forces up to 30G during test flights, promising news for astronaut health during long-term missions.

articles.title: When and Where You Can Ride the NEW Bluey Ride

articles.author: Lauren Writtenberry
articles.content: While we still have not seen Bluey spotted at Disney World yet, there is one place you will be able to ride a Bluey-themed attraction soon!  Bluey and Bingo!  Its no secret that Bluey has taken the w‚Ä¶ [+2329 chars]
articles.full_text: While we still have not seen Bluey spotted at Disney World yet, there is one place you will be able to ride a Bluey-themed attraction soon! Bluey and Bingo! It‚Äôs no secret that Bluey has taken the world by storm. The Australian pup and her lovable Heeler family have turned everyday moments into must-watch adventures, winning over kids and adults alike. With its mix of heart, humor, and life lessons, the show has become one of the most beloved family series in recent years. Now, Bluey is ready to leap from the screen into the theme park world. Bluey fans, it‚Äôs time to pack your bags, because everyone‚Äôs favorite blue pup is about to get her very own ride! That‚Äôs right, the lovable Heeler family is heading to the theme park world in a major way. Alton Towers Resort in the United Kingdom has announced that CBeebies Land will be home to the world‚Äôs first-ever Bluey ride, set to open in spring 2026. If you‚Äôre already thinking, ‚ÄúHow do I get there?‚Äù ‚Äî trust us, we‚Äôre right there with you. ¬©Alton Towers But the fun doesn‚Äôt stop at the ride. Visitors will also be able to enjoy Heeler family meet-and-greets, a live Bluey experience inside Big Fun Showtime, and even what Alton Towers calls the ultimate Bluey sleepover. Yes, the CBeebies Land Hotel is offering immersive Bluey-themed rooms where you‚Äôll feel like you‚Äôve stepped straight into the cartoon itself. If you‚Äôre wondering whether I‚Äôm tempted to book a plane ticket across the pond immediately‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs just say my suitcase is already half-packed. ¬©Alton Towers Disney already teased in 2024 that Bluey would be joining Disneyland Resort in California and Walt Disney World in Florida, as well as Disney Cruise Line, sometime in the future. So far, her official debut has only happened at sea, but the announcement of a full ride overseas could signal that BBC is ready to bring even bigger Bluey plans to life. ¬©Alton Towers On January 10th, Bluey and Bingo made their Disney Cruise Line debut on sailings originating from Australia and New Zealand. The Heeler sisters have been making a splash on board, with a character meet and greet and an interactive game, and a dance party. A total dream for Bluey fans! Bluey! Until then, we‚Äôll be keeping a close eye on both Alton Towers and Disney‚Äôs next moves. Whether you‚Äôre in the U.K. or the U.S., it feels like Bluey‚Äôs theme park era is just getting started. Be sure you keep following Disney Food Blog for more news on theme parks. Which Disney World park do you think Bluey would be great at? Tell us in the comments below!
articles.rewritten_text: Alton Towers Resort in the UK will unveil the world's first Bluey-themed ride in spring 2026 at CBeebies Land. The attraction will feature meet-and-greets with the Heeler family, live shows, and themed hotel rooms. Bluey already appears on Disney Cruise Line sailings from Australia.
